review_title: Expensive Lightweight and Portable Chromebook- Beautiful Touchscreen
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on December 2, 2021
review_text: I want to start off by saying this is my first experience with the ChromeOS.  I have used iOS and Windows extensively- but have wanted to give ChromeOS a try to see how it measured up.  There was a slight learning curve, but once I got up and running it was pretty easy to figure out.  I have been using the Chromebook for a few weeks now for light work that is web-based and playing some lower end games via apps and have found both positive and negative points.The positives:- The touchscreen functionality works well and is a great asset to have both for work and games.  The touchscreen is responsive and feels sturdy.- This Acer Chromebook is lightweight and very portable while still having a large enough screen for easy visualization with the 13" screen.- The battery life is exceptional- I have used it off and on for over a full day without having to charge the battery.-  The optional slot for a SIM card is a great feature so that the Chromebook can be used on the 4G LTE network.-  The screen has very good resolution with sharp rich colors in 1080 HD. It is a great option for streaming movies on the go.-  A decent amount of memory at 8GB is included.- Can be used with Chrome Enterprise if using for business/academic purposes for ease of management.-  Powers up quickly with the SSD and is ready to go in seconds.- Keyboard is backlit- which I feel is a must have when using a laptop in a lower light environment.- 2 USB C ports and 1 USB-A port along with a 3.5 mm headphones jack are included.The negatives:-  The flash storage is small compared to other similar sized laptops- at 128 GB this is more akin to a tablet or phone.- Keyboard it smaller and does not have a separate number pad.-  There is no SD slot for adding memory.-  ChromeOS does have a slight learning curve for a new user.-  I noticed somewhat frequent app crashes when I was playing games, especially when waking from hibernation with the lid closed.  I had to force close the app using the Ctrl+W several times and found the alert that ChromeOS had restarted unexpectedly after an error.  There were also some instances where opening multiple tabs in the web browser caused the OS to freeze.- Priced somewhat high compared to other similar laptops.Overall, this  Chromebook is a nice product for light use.  It has a beautiful touchscreen display and long battery life while being light weight and small enough to fit in most bags/purses/carry on easily.  It has enough memory and storage with the SSD to make it an attractive option for travel or use at school/work when not needing any higher end computing functions.  I really like the ability to add the SIM card for cellular network access- making it truly portable.  While it is somewhat pricey, depending on your needs, each individual needs to do comparison shopping with similar windows/Mac products to see what fits best.While I did notice some issues with the Chrome OS- while they are annoying, as of this point they were not enough for me to give it a negative review as I didn't lose any data and the Chromebook restarts very quickly.  I will update if anything changes.  This Chromebook is definitely worth looking at to see if it meets your needs.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on December 31, 2023
review_text: Two months in and it's still doing great.  My only complaint is that the touch screen is a bit too sensitive (there's probably some way to adjust it but I don't know how).

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on November 15, 2021
review_text: As I sit here typing away on this little Chromebook, I reflect that Acer and netbooks-now-Chromebooks have come a long way.  Back in the early 90s, I got my first PC, and it was an Acer.  At that time, it was a no-name brand that was simply cheap.  Today, Acer is a household name, and Chromebooks one of its specialties.  Chromebooks, the love child of early tablets and low powered netbooks, has also taken off. For light duty computing, they’re hard to ignore in terms of size and price.  It’s no wonder that schools use them, being small, light, cheap to replace, and easy to manage.  This one here has gone corporate, which is a new one to me.  Does it really have a place in the business world, particularly at a price point equal to that of a light laptop?  Maybe.  With the whole Office suite available online, rather than needing a PC install, this could work.  Of course, there are all the Google equivalents of the Office apps, but there are still some compatibility issues between the two that can be a pain to deal with.  But let's look at how this little machine does.First off, the performance is really good.  Compared to the school Chromebooks that are hanging around the house, this is a race horse compared to draft horses.  Multitasking is no problem, nor the 20 some odd Chromebook tabs I tend to have open.  Scrolling through docs, webpages, and menus is lickity split quick.  Video playback is smooth, both on and off the web,  Sound….well….it’s there.  It exists, it works, but nothing to write home about.  Ditto for the webcam.  Using the camera for document scanning is not something that I’d suggest with this model, unless you are hooking up an external camera, See the attached images for an idea of what that looks like.  The screen is quite nice visually, though the touch can be a bit unresponsive.  I found this tended to be in the corners, and not constant.  The touchpad is quite responsive, and took me some getting used to (I detest touchpads, opting for a wireless mouse whenever possible).  The battery life is, well, pretty awesome.  In the month I’ve spent using this on and off (a few hours here, a few hours there), I think I’ve charged it up four times.  There are unused tablets around my house that require charging more frequently.Overall, this is a very nice Chromebook.  Is it worth the 600-800 asking price?  Personally, I couldn’t say yes to that.  It’s like asking if a Civic is worth forty grand.  Sure, it’s really nice, but it’s still a Chromebook, with all the limitations that implies.5 stars - Excellent/Perfect - This is the stuff right here, folks!  Rare gem.4 stars - Good/Great - Has a lot going for it, even if not perfect3 stars - Ok - Not bad, but doesn’t have anything particularly special about it2 stars - Not so good - More cons than pros on this little number1 star - Don’t walk, run away - No redeeming qualities

review_title: Even a top of the line Chromebook is still a Chromebook
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on March 10, 2022
review_text: Acer Chromebook Enterprise Spin 513: $736.93 at the time of reviewI’m going to be honest, I didn’t *need* a Chromebook when I ordered this. I have a personal laptop and a work laptop so I wasn’t in the market for another. However, I work in a company that uses Google Enterprise and I’ve been thinking about testing a Chromebook in that capacity for a long time. So when the opportunity popped up right in front of my face I had to take it.*What I liked*:The very first thing you’ll notice about this laptop (before even turning it on) is that it’s very light. But it still manages to feel solid when closed thanks to the aluminum lid. This is actually pretty important as the screen is so thin that I don’t think a plastic top would protect it well enough.The next thing that stands out (and is, in fact, outstanding) is the beautiful IPS 1080p display. It is crisp with vibrant colors and at 13.3” the pixel density is excellent (at about 165 PPI). This means that things will look sharp.I also like that the display is touchscreen (with the ability to flip the screen over flat to enable a kind of tablet mode)The performance is also great for Chromebook. With 8GB of RAM and a decent Qualcomm Snapdragon processor driving it, it can handle just about anything that Chrome OS can throw at it.It’s also worth noting that it is outfitted with 2 USB-C 3.2 ports for charging, data, and accessories. And it is very well-equipped on the wireless front too with Wireless AC as well as Bluetooth 5.0.*What I didn't like*:Unfortunately for all of the places that this Chromebook accels, it seems to have a corresponding weakness, starting with the case. While the aluminum lid is nice and provides good stability when closed, the bottom of the case is all plastic and suffers from pretty bad top case & keyboard flex.The screen, while gorgeous, caps out at a maximum brightness that suffers in full daylight. If you’re using this outside in sunlight, you may have problems reading things.I won’t rag on the performance, as it is quite good. However, I will say that I felt limited by ChromeOS in this regard. What good is a Mustang if they only let you drive 25Mph? The programs I did use were snappy, but good luck finding something that will actually test the guts of this thing.*Things you Should Know:*As I mentioned above, I ordered this Chromebook to test it as a business use case. My organization uses Google Workspace as it’s primary collaboration and productivity suite. I was hoping to identify a cost effective alternative to more expensive laptops that I could start deploying to my user base.I found this laptop to be a very suitable option for business-class computing. If that’s your goal, then you could do a lot worse than this, especially considering that it is Enterprise-ready.*The Bottom Line:*As a laptop for general use and computing, this Chromebook from Acer isn’t half bad. However, the compromises in build quality are unacceptable at this price point. There are *much* better options (both business and consumer-grade) for nearly $750. I hemmed and hawed over where to land on the ole star scale. In the end, because this is targeted at business user and in the sector, $750 is a somewhat reasonable price for a laptop, I settled on four stars out of five. But if you’re a regular old consumer, your $750 will buy you a much better laptop right here on Amazon. I would not order this over again knowing what I know now.

review_title: If you're into ChromeOS, here's a Rolls Royce
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on November 15, 2021
review_text: My old Windows laptops are nearing the end of their lifecycles. I didn't think a Chromebook would meet my needs, since most of them seem relatively underpowered. But I figured I'd give this high-end model a shot.This is easily the most portable laptop I've ever owned. It's the size and thickness of a paper notebook,and nearly as lightweight. Despite this, the keyboard (which is backlit!) is essentially full-sized, andfeels great under the fingers.The 13" screen offers full HD (1920 x 1080) native resolution, which is both a blessing (when watching movies and/or using multiple apps) and a curse (when trying to read text, which can be a challenge at this size/scale). Luckily, the virtual dimensions of the display are easily upscaled, and the quality of the upscaled image is outstanding, unlike many Windows devices, which become noticeably pixelated. The touchscreen works as expected, though I almost always use a mouse.Aside from a 1/8" stereo headphone jack, there are only three ports: a pair of USC-C 3.2 Gen 1s whichboth support charging/power delivery and/or DisplayPort output, and a single USB-A 3.2 Gen 1 port. This arrangement may be adequate for many users, but if you use multiple peripherals like I do, you'll probably want to obtain a USB-C hub, preferably one that supports power delivery. The DesertWesthub I use gives me three USB-A ports, an HDMI output, an Ethernet jack and slots for several different types of memory cards. All of the ports work flawlessly with the Chromebook, including the HDMI, whichlets me connect the laptop to almost any external monitor or HDTV.Added bonus: You can connect a SIM card and run the laptop off 4G cellphone towers. Very handy for frequent travelers.I typically use a laptop as the control center for HD music listening. My library resides on an external4TB HDD, and my playback rig is a Schiit Modi 3 DAC driving a Magni 2 headphone amp. I'm happy to report that this Chromebook drives my setup with no issues at all when I plug the Modi directly into the USB-A port. (It would probably work through a USB-C hub as well, though I haven't tried it.) Both of my preferred audio apps (Neutron and Foobar2000) are available on the Chrome store and operate as expected.Hard to fault the performance. This Acer powers up in seconds, connects to every wireless device I've tried effortlessly, and runs off a fully-charged battery for the better part of a day. Web browsing with Chrome is as brisk as my most powerful desktops. Web-based apps like Zoom, Slack and VS Code are also highly responsive, and so are the handful of apps I've downloaded from the Chrome store.The 128GB onboard memory is skimpy by Windows standards. There's no built-in memory card slot (an odd and annoying omission that cost my review 1 star), but it's easily and cheaply expandable via the slots available on most USB-C hubs. A 128 GB MicroSD card will double this laptop's capacity for less than $20.The biggest issue with this unit is its price. At nearly $800, it's competing with a number of Windows 10/11 laptops with similar specifications/feature sets. But if you're accustomed to the ChromeOS ecosystem, or just want a zippy laptop/tablet that's ultra-portable and stupid-easy to use, this high-end Acer is worth serious consideration.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on December 23, 2023
review_text: I bought for my dad who uses it to play games

review_title: Adequate performance, good battery life, supports LTE, comparatively expensive
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on October 17, 2021
review_text: When Google first envisioned computers based on ChromeOS, Chromebooks, they were to be a lightweight, inexpensive, relatively unhackable alternative to those based on Windows, but far more user friendly than those based on Linux (though Linux remains at the core of ChromeOS, so it's really an interfacial skin on Linux).This focus led to the first generation of ChromeOS devices, which were universally low-powered and mostly with fairly cheap components. But through the years, Google has improved ChromeOS to increase functionality, and, in more recent years, to support access to the Linux kernel to lure hardcore computer programmers to the platform.As a result, alongside very cheap low-grade Chromebooks that just barely get by with dismal screens and nominal processing power and memory, you have newer, considerably more expensive variants that offer beefed-up performance, better screens, better keyboards, etc. Some of these can cost North of $1000, in comparison to entry-level machines that are often available for under $200.This particular Chromebook clocks in near the top of that price range, and so you'd expect it to be promising top line preformance and components. The reality is that you get some nice features and hardware, but, ultimately, the price is high relative to the full package.The justification for the high price is the inclusion of a 4G LTE modem. This means you can insert an LTE data SIM from your phone provider to be connected without having to worry about a WiFi signal. If you don't need this capability, then there are PLENTY of alternate Chromebooks with similar specs--some from Acer, but also from other name brands--that cost roughly half of what this one does.The 1920x1080 LED/TFT touchscreen is quite nice: Vibrant, bright, accurate, and the kind of screen you'd expect on a Chromebook at this price point. While the chicklet-type keyboard is nothing special, it's certainly comfortable to use. And you get 8Gb of memory. All fine.But for some reason, Acer has chosen to go with the Qualcomm Snapdragon 7c processor. This is two-year-old technology that is sufficient for simple stuff like Web surfing but starts to choke on more demanding tasks. There are plenty of mid/high end Chromebooks powered by Intel processors that do a better job with compute-hungry applicaitons, while maintaining good battery life. Acer even makes a number of these. So I can't quite understand why they went with the 7c in this relatively expensive package.Connecting using a SIM card is trivial: Merely insert it in the tray, and the Chromebook recognizes it, and you're set up and connected in less than a minute. I got pretty good speeds using my AT&T SIM, getting nearly 60 MB/s down. If you have both a SIM installed and WiFi access, the Chromebook will automatically prioritize WiFi with the LTE as a backup.A device like this is often used for media consumption (watching streaming videos, for example). So the quality of the built-in speakers makes a difference. And the speakers here are poor: Thin sounding and not very loud. It doesn't help that they fire downward with the laptop in standard (keyboard in front of you) position. In fliptop mode (make a "tee pee" with the laptop for viewing, with the keyboard behind the monitor), the speakers sound a bit better. But they are still lousy for a Chreomebook at this price point.A summary of pros and cons:Pros:** Supports 4G SIM card connections** 8Gb of memory** Very light and portable** Good screen: Vibrant and bright** Touchscreen** Decent battery life (9-10 hours on a full charge)** Standard USB-C charging port** Free Chrome Enterprise upgrade included (personal users won't find this very useful)Cons** Uses outdated and underpowered Qualcomm Snapdragon 7C processor** Mediocre low cost eMMC storage** Limited interaction ports (2x USB-C, 1x USB-A, headphone jack). USB ports only support USB 3.2 r1 (5 MB/s)** No SmartMedia slot** Integrated webcam is low resolution (1280x720) and not very bright** Integrated speakers are poorOn the whole, the only real selling point for this Chromebook at the given price is the LTE modem. if you want a Chromebook that supports that functionality, you don't have a huge number of options, and this is a reasonable one. But if you won't be using that, then there are plenty of better options for Chromebooks with Intel processors, good battery life, and a lower list price.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on October 19, 2021
review_text: I’ve always been a ‘PC Guy’.  But I’ve seen a lot of advertisements lately about the advantages of using a Chromebook instead.  So I figured it was high time to give one a try.After a bit of searching and comparing models, I decided to purchase the Acer Enterprise Spin 513.  I did so for a few reasons.  Firstly, Acer is a brand that I recognize.  A lot of the Chromebook books I saw were off-brands, so I was unsure of what I’d be get.  Acer I knew I could trust.Secondly, this Acer Spun 513 is a touch screen laptop.  I actually didn’t know how much I would use the touch feature…I hardly ever use it on my Windows laptop….but I figured it was better to have it than not.  Besides, I didn’t know how using a touchpad on a Chromebook would be, so it was a bit of ‘added security’ for me.Third, this Acer Spun 513 was one of the few Chromebooks I saw that featured a backlit keyboard.  That is something I won’t go without.  It makes it do much easier to use any laptop…or even desktop for that fact.  That was probably the major selling point for me on this unit.Setup on the Acer Spin 513 was a breeze.  All I had to do was connect it to my wifi and put in my Google account credentials, and I was ready to go.  There was so much less drama in the whole process than setup a Windows computer.This Chromebook provides you with an upgrade to the ‘Enterprise’ edition if you want,  i was unsure of what the ‘enterprise edition’ actually was, so I opted out of it during setup.  I discovered later it was more geared for users who work from home and includes a lot of added security features among other things.  I’ll maybe go back and set my Google account up as an Enterprise one…if I still can.My opinion is that it’s just an Android phone in a laptop body.  So, if you’re an Android user this thing should be a piece of cake to navigate.  The Google Play Store is there as are a lot of the apps you find on an Android phone.  Being an Apple guy, it took a bit for me to get used to it.  But one I did, things were great.The Acer Spin 513 Chromebook seems to be a very capable machine.  It’s fast and doesn’t drag in the least.  The touchscreen is a little quirky, but maybe it’s just me.  It will probably take some practice getting used to as I’m used to a substantially larger screen than this 13” model.  The colors on the screen are bright and clear, and the resolution is amazing.  Videos look so good on this machine.The Spin 513 Chromebook comes with 8 gb of ram and a 128gb SSD installed which is definitely enough power to run most of the apps you can install.  You can upgrade the memory by adding a card.  You’ll need that if you want to store a lot of pics or videos.The Acer Spin 513 charges via one of the two USB C ports.  There is one each side which makes it convenient to keep the power cord out of the way.  And the battery does last a long time.  I ran it all day without a hitch.There is also a USB 3.2 port on the Acer Spin 513 Chromebook as well as a ‘Display Port over USB C’ to add a second monitor if you wish.  USC is becoming very common on laptops these days.One other neat feature on the Spin 513 is the built-in 4G.  Just like with an Android phone, if you don’t have wifi, the Chromebook will switch over to using cellular data.  If a nice feature if you’re on the go a lot.  But rem, it does cost for the service.All-in-all, I think the Acer Spin 513 is a very nice Chromebook.  It has a lot of useful features and performed well for the everyday tasks Zi put it through.  And it also wasn’t to awkward using it in the tablet configuration.  And it’s capable enough to use in a business environment.  It’s a little pricey, but I recommend it.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on November 23, 2023
review_text: I really love my Chromebook

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on October 23, 2021
review_text: This latest Chromebook spin is thin and lightweight. Weighting only 1.2 Kg. It can be used as both, a standard laptop, or you can spin it into a semi tablet design utilizing its hinge. You can flip the screen for 360-degrees but, you can’t detach the keyboard and touchpad.Performance wise, the Octa-core Snapdragon 7c CPU and 8 GB RAM now standard in this newer model as well as the SSD storage capacity allowed for multitasking with relative ease and speed for everyday work.The Octa-core Snapdragon 7c is almost 4 generations behind the latest Qualcomm Snapdragon 8cx Gen 2 5G.Also,  Snapdragon by Qualcomm provides better battery performance vs Intel processors in my opinion.The display resolution is Full HD (1920 x 1080 pixels) with touchscreen. The Resolution is great for a 13.3” display. Screen type is LCD with LED backlight technology. When tested outdoors, the screen had good viewing angles, good colors and relatively good brightness utilizing the power of its IPS panel. However, it appeared dim with strong daylight.The presence of a SIM slot allowed for using the laptop on the go with relative ease utilizing its up-to-4G powered networks.The 4670 mAh battery capacity allows for efficient use for a full working day of heavy use with the screen on relatively high brightness levels, which is a positive point.Some of the points in my opinion to support this high price, is that this being an enterprise version meaning: it has a faster processor for work needs, a fast SSD hard drive, an 8GB RAM, Free Chrome enterprise package. The free Chrome enterprise package is good for companies whose IT department can log in easily to employees' chromebooks and perform necessary IT tasks. This may not be a very useful point for normal users.In summary, this Chromebook gave a minimalistic, easy and very fast experience. I myself nearly live my life on the web. So, for basic/medium daily computing and online work, this Chromebook can be sufficient.The price it self is justifiable for normal users who love chromebooks (Except for the price premium added for Chrome Enterprise), as it has a light operating system that can be faster than many expensive smart phones when using similar mobile apps but with a much bigger screen.So it's really more about comparing this to advanced and expensive smart phones who can easily achieve $800+ to give a fair comparison rather than just comparing this to heavy duty laptopsOptions and features to consider in the future? I would recommend higher storage capacity in the future. I would also recommend a detachable keyboard and touchpad as well as higher screen resolution and brightness for greater sharpness and better overall experience.

review_title: A good Chromebook, but for the price better devices are available.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on October 17, 2021
review_text: When I think of Chromebooks, I usually  think of  a system for kids or a person that could do all required daily tasks on the Web.Using the Acer Chromebook Enterprise Spin 513 for several days have not improved my perspective about Chromebooks.Even though Chromebooks have come a long way, since they were introduced, still much more can be done with a laptop running Windows, MacOS, and even a Linux distro. Chromebooks could run apps such as Microsoft Office, but the mobile app version does not offer all features available on a laptop.Still some apps cannot run on a wide screen and they default to running on the center of the Chromebook.The Acer Chromebook Enterprise Spin 513 is made of aluminum, which allows a light and thin construction and it is quite portable at 2.8 pounds. It has 360 degree hinges and the bezels on left, right and top are reasonably small, with enough space to hold it as a tablet.This Acer Chromebook, has a Qualcomm Snapdragon 7c with LTE capabilities, in case you want to be always connected with a data plan.The Spin 513 has a good 1920 x 1080 crisp screen, bright enough for use outdoors...in the shade of course.The keyboard is backlit, and it is comfortable enough when typing and the touchpad is quite responsive with a smooth Gorilla Glass surface.What make Chromebooks appealing is the price, portability and long battery life. They could run productivity web apps as well as  Android apps from the Google Play store.The Acer Chromebook Enterprise Spin 513 battery could last a couple of days work without need to recharge. Even though the included AC to USB C charger is bulky, it could be charge with smaller chargers that can deliver the required power.The 720 Webcam is ok, as good as many other Chromebooks, and Windows laptops. It perform very well with video conferencing. The stereos speakers are very good for a thin laptop, but connecting pretty much any headphones (earbuds) will improve the sound quality.There is a 3.5mm combination audio jack that works with headsets, headphones or even a Mic, just in case you have wired devices or Bluetooth is not a choice.Acer Chromebook Enterprise Spin 513 has 2 USB Type-C 3.2 (Gen 1) ports that supports DisplayPort over USB-C and USB Charging.You could charge the Chromebook from either side and plugging an external display was a breeze. Just plug a display via a USB Type-C port and you could double the monitor real state. Depending of the external display it could also draw power from the Chromebook.It also has a USB 3.2 (Gen 1) Type-A port and a Nano SIM Slot. Besides those ports it also has Accelerometer, Gyroscope, Orientation, Game rotation vector sector and a Gravity sensor.This Acer Chromebook is very good for Google Classroom and it could work for students as well as teachers. I do think is overpriced at $800. There are many Chromebooks and tablets with similar performance and features that cost half the price. Even other units, from the same manufacturer, that perform better cost less.There are less expensive Windows laptops that could do everything this Acer Chromebook Enterprise Spin 513 can do. They could do it faster and could also perform other more demanding tasks that the Spin 513 can not perform. Also, it could have features the Enterprise Spin 513 lacks, such as WiFi 6 and SD card reader...and even be lighter.It could be that the addition of that LTE radio added to the price, since the ones without LTE cost a lot less. But LTE and even faster 5G could be added to pretty much any laptop via a USB dongle...if necessary.I have a high speed Internet service and this Chromebook can only reach half the download speed available. A similar price Windows laptop can reach 3x the download speed when connected to WiFi 6.By the way, the Acer Chromebook Enterprise Spin 513 arrived with a 3-year old Android version 9 (Pie). Some apps I used, were not compatible and since they require Android version 10 or newer.Also there isn't a hardware upgrade path, since all components are soldered to the mainboard.I ran several benchmarks and the scores were ok but lower than a less expensive 11" inch 2-year old Android tablet I also use.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on October 30, 2023
review_text: He loves this laptop/tablet. It is really helpful for him in doing his homework.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on October 23, 2023
review_text: This computer is very fast and responsive. It blows my 5 and 10 year old chromebook and laptop completely out of the water with its performance and ergonomics.

review_title: The only negative I have is the price tag...
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on October 18, 2021
review_text: So I work in IT and did a 1:1 deployment of Chromebooks 6-7 years ago when they were still a new thing and right after that deployment I left education and hadn't touched one since. I got this more for the house and for me and my wife to use in bed, but I decided to daily drive it for a week.My normal daily driver laptop is a Lenovo with a 5000 series ryzen and 16gb of ram. I wasn't expecting to use it much past emails and conference room meetings but it did well for most of the week. First in meetings, it was great had multiple tabs and added an outlook app that I could pin to the task bar. While at a lunch meeting I had a service issue and had to do a screen share and remotely control a computer so I quickly downloaded Webex and Splashtop (what we use) and my Webex call went well with no hiccups. Splashtop however is designed for a tablet setup and struggled some but worked well enough for me to get my work done on a remote server. All in all in a pinch it works but you must know its limitations.Now for what I'm actually going to use it for home use. For the home side having most of my work stuff setup on my login it will work well for any late-night calls and I won't have to leave the bed to get to my desktop or grab a laptop from the car. My wife used it for several hours shopping and it didn't get too hot sitting on top of a fleece blanket which was nice.Screen size is good and 1080p is perfect, the touch seems good, I'm an old mac user and still not a fan of touch screen laptops mostly due to smuges lol.Performance-wise its fine, 8gb of ram and a larger SSD is going to be required to try to justify the price point but the chassis is good but not perfect. Very minor deck flex but doesn't feel premium...Final thoughts:For the same price, I can go to BestBuy and get a 8 core 16 thread AMD-powered laptop with 16gb of ram and 512SSD... If this is at the $400 price point it would be very easy for me to recommend but at $800 I think you can buy something with more flexibility...

review_title: Great Quality Screen, Nice Feature set, Good Performance
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on October 27, 2021
review_text: The excellent battery life high quality screen, connectivity and ultra light weight make this Chromebook an excellent choice for anyone that doesn't really want or need the heavy, shorter battery life of a windows laptop. Especially for cell phone users looking for a little more power and something that pairs well with a phone.One of its strongest features is the USB-C connectivity, I was able to connect a multi function dongle to the laptop, plug in a 4k monitor (see the attached photos), connect a full sized keyboard, and a mouse without any issues. The dongle then just sits on my desk with all the hardware hooked up to it, and if I want to connect the laptop to the entire works, I just plug the USB-C plug into the side and away I go. Love that!The battery life if also excellent. I ended up stuck in  a parking garage waiting for someone at a hospital for FIVE hours!(they didn't want vistors because of our little friend mr 19) Where I proceeded to play Frogger the entire time. The battery started with half a charge on it, and was just running out of power when it was time to leave. I don't have any background apps running on the laptop so that extended the battery too. But five hours of frogger is excellent for half a battery!Chromebooks in general give up compute power to gain battery life, the CPU on this is an 8 core model but each core has fairly limited compute capabilities, this means that any app that can't take advantage of all those cores could have issues. This Chormebook has a fairly powerful CPU compared to other Chromebooks, but a good windows laptop will run circles around it.The touchscreen on this Chromebook is outstanding and is a good reason to go with this model. It has excellent color, contrast and brightness. The keyboard is a compact but very useable. It has the dents to help lost fingers find "home" and the backlighting is fairly smart, shutting off when I'm not using the keyboard and picking up the lightest touch to turn the backlights on again.The Chrome OS is still maturing and its Linux heritage comes through in several respects, for power users, the Chrome browser acts like a shell where commands can be entered. Also many Google store apps assume a cellphone shaped screen and can't take advantage of the extra screen space.If you have a home that also has Windows computers (like us) this laptop uses a Linux tool that used to be know as Samba for connectivity to windows shares. In the Chrome OS it is possible to connect to those shares with SMB connections but everything has to be setup just right and it can be a pain to connect. Once connected it works well though.This Chromebook lacks orientation sensors which I was hoping it would have,  I would really like to be able to put the laptop on edge while writing papers and have the full length of the screen be usable. (with a keyboard connected via USB) I also can't find a setting that allows me to force it to do that.I wish I had this laptop in college, it would be perfect carrying to class, recording lectures(though it doesn't have a rear facing camera), writing papers, and electronic socializing. Plus it has just enough CPU horsepower to keep all those apps fairly snappy.Running windows: This question is bound to come up and I don't see any reason why this couldn't run windows 10, for windows 11, the CPU is listed under the supported CPU's, it looks like this has the right secruity hardware, but I don't see a UEFI on this laptop which windows 11 requires.Overall this Chromebook is an easy 5 stars with a great feature set and good performance.

review_title: started off great but freezing up and glitching now
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on November 12, 2021
review_text: so first off im going to say that i'm not a chromebook guy, i've always felt that you would be better off with a budget windows laptop simply because the options out there were not great. after using this chromebook for a month my views have changed.chromebooks have always been mostly good for entertainment with a side of light office work, they usually have good screens and great battery life but lack the software support for most users as well as a dismal app selection. i still feel that most users would be better off buying a good mid range laptop for most uses. having said that i feel like this chromebook is the exception to that rule. the cpu is snappy and quickly opens apps and websites, the storage on this is far better than most out there and while its not as good as a laptop with a nvme for storage space, it boots up faster than my usual go to asus laptop which starts up in around 6 seconds. the screen on this thing is beautiful, the colors are sharp and vibrant without being faded or washed out and the brightness is perfect for indoor use and some outdoor use. the keyboard is comfortable and easy to type on without sounding loud and clanky.this model even includes a sim card slot so you can get stuff done even when you don't have wifi around. i tested it out and got strong 4g reception and good download speeds. the tablet modes cool for watching movies on, but its a bit to large to carry it around and use it that way for long but you could totally do that if you want since the touchscreen is so responsive. this chromebook is so good that i've been reaching for it whenever i want to browse or shop on amazon. in fact id say that this chromebook has become my go to device for most stuff other than gaming or anything i absolutely have to have windows for. now, i'm going to point out that this version is more than most decent mid range laptops,in fact its pretty expensive compared to the vast majority of chromebooks i've seen, is it worth it? the answer is a strong maybe. i've been so thrilled with this chromebook for the month i've been using it that i would have said absolutely until a couple days ago when i started having some troubling issues with it.it started out popping up a message that chrome hadn't shut down correctly and asked if i wanted to restore apps, i figured it was a simple error and hoped it wouldn't repeat. unfortunately it did, and then some. in the last three days its started randomly popping up black barcode areas on the screen, they go away if i turn it off and back on but its usually indicative of an issue with the graphics chip getting to hot, not something id expect on a chromebook, especially simply browsing the internet. then it started freezing up and i would have to hold the power button down to force a reboot so it would work again. now i am assuming its an error with the hardware but it could also be an issue with the chrome os update it got a little over a week ago, i haven't heard any other issues from people so i'm still leaning towards a hardware issue and will be reaching out to acer support to resolve this problem. i've bought acer laptops before and have always had good experiences with them so hopefully this time wont be any different.i will update this review once i get that figured out but for now i'm going to have to give it a 2 star rating. for a chromebook costing this much i wouldn't expect to have issues, especially this soon, but i also understand that hardware issues happen to every company. if these issues weren't going on id definitely give this a 5 star, its completely changed my view of chromebooks.

review_title: Can't set up computer. Can't return it.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on November 16, 2023
review_text: After taking three weeks to arrive I found upon initial set-up the computer says Network Not Available despite being connected to a network (can use internet as a guest on the laptop). Tried several different wifi connections. Reset computer. Went through trouble shooting and unable to resolve. Decided to send back. Computer has lithiom ion batters can't be sent by UPS ground according to local UPS (I live on an island in Alaska). Amazon send ground label. Called customer service. Amazon sent ground label again. UPS has now marked package wasn't ready be picked up. Called Amazon again, said only option they have is to print ground label. Amazon says I can pay for extra shipping if needed and get reimbursed, which I don't really trust will happen since they can't send a correct label initially. I might just be stuck with a computer I can't use.

Great battery life3. Very light Weight great for travel4. Foldable into tablet mode5. Very easy to use and easy to understand6. Touch screen works just like a tablet7. usb-c charging method8. When in tablet mode chromebook does not fold/closed entirely ( i hate that lose gap ) *look at picture3. I tested it out to play PUBG or COD ( Horrible!!! Don’t do it lol ) NOT MADE FOR GAMING4. review_title: More than capable replacement for Windows PC
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on October 24, 2021
review_text: I needed a lightweight highly mobile laptop and surprisingly, this Chromebook fit the bill. I was using a Windows Ultrabook but between poor battery life and worsening hardware issues, I found myself quickly needing a replacement. I was already in the process of evaluating this Acer and decided to give it a try. I had initial doubts that a Chromebook could handle all my professional needs, but I also realized the majority of my apps are web based.  This model also isn’t an ordinary Chromebook. It’s designed for business use and has the enterprise option for managed hardware environments. I don’t currently need or use the enterprise enrollment feature but it’s nice to know it’s there if things change.The size and build quality are perfect for frequent transport. The bottom half is plastic, but the lid has an attractive brushed metal finish with polished beveled edges. It’s both attractive and lightweight yet has a sturdy solid feel. There are two USB-C ports. Either port can be used to charge the Chromebook. There are also a USB-type A port, a 3.5mm audio jack,  and a SIM compartment for cellular connectivity. The FHD screen is bright and vivid. Graphics are sharp and crisp with good color saturation and refresh rate. The touchscreen feature is reliably responsive and allows the Chromebook to be used in tablet or tent mode if desired. The backlit keyboard keys have a solid feeling keystroke with good actuation. The muti-touch trackpad seems to work well but I personally can’t stand using trackpads, so I use a USB mouse or the touchscreen.Performance is excellent. I’ve had Chromebooks in the past that felt sluggish and slow. This Chromebook is quick and instantly responsive. It does not at all feel like a Chromebook. It works fine with MS Teams, MS Office apps, my IP phone app and my RMM sites. My only complaint is some of the apps are formatted for mobile devices and don’t appear the same as they do on their Windows counterparts. For example, Teams only works in a small portrait window which leads me to believe it’s the phone version. No Chromebook-specific version is available. Outlook also alerted me that Office apps are being discontinued on Chromebooks and suggested I use OWA. Thankfully, Google Office apps are available offline if needed. So, performance is excellent but there are some compromises with certain apps, mostly from Microsoft. All of my web-based apps work fine, and I can remotely connect to and manage networking hardware as well as servers and other workstations without any issues.  Battery life is outstanding.  I typically use this machine powered on with sleep disabled all day and usually get a full two days of use between charges.The webcam, like most integrated webcams, is mediocre at best. It works okay in well-lit areas but gets noticeably dark and grainy if lighting is less than optimal. The camera also has a scan function for scanning documents and QR codes. The document “scanner” is basically a content aware photograph of the document that can be saved as either a photo file or PDF. The scanner doesn’t perform any transformation or OCR and it also requires bright lighting for best results. It also isn’t the easiest feature to use given that the camera is embedded in the screen and the document should preferably be positioned on a flat surface. If the camera is facing the document, how do you know it’s properly lined up? The document scanner is a good but badly executed. The microphone quality is good. Voices are clear and distortion free with good default gain. The speakers, however, are another story and leave much to be desired. They’re okay for productivity and videoconferencing but that’s about it. They’re flat sounding, not very loud and have zero resonance. Multimedia like music and movies sound flat and lifeless. Even a small set of external speakers would be a marked improvement if planning to use this for presentations or regularly watching or listening to multimedia.One neat feature of this Chromebook is that it effortlessly pairs to Android devices. It paired easily with my Android phone and even automatically configured text forwarding and automatic hotspot. When out and about, if I need internet, the Chromebook automatically connects to my phone.  That’s assuming I decide not to just insert a dedicated SIM card for the Chromebook. One thing’s for sure, this little laptop provides several extras and options. I had my doubts, but it has been a marvelous work machine and I do not at all miss my prior Windows laptop. Yes, this Chromebook carries a premium price compared to others, but as an owner of four Chromebooks in the past, this is by far the best looking, best performing and most like a Windows machine as far as overall performance. The screen quality, build quality and performance are more on par with a decent Windows machine around the same price rather than the typical Chromebook. It’s less than an inch thick and light as a feather yet doesn’t feel cheap or fragile.

review_title: Best of both tablet and laptop worlds - with power to spare
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on October 17, 2021
review_text: Here's the features I really like about this one: * Thin and light - smaller than an iPad Pro 12.9 * Practically instant boot-up.  When you open it, it's ready to use. * Fits nicely on the lap, without the heat issues you get with a traditional laptop. * When in full tablet mode, the screen is very responsive with no lag at all. * Using it in tablet presentation mode, it takes up very little desk space and is great for watching shows. * Display is bright and vivid. * Battery life is very impressive and remaining life is accurately captured. * I have not tried it, but the cellular data will be a nice feature for traveling or camping.  Came with 2GB of data to try. * Besides the startup and shutdown performance, normal operations are quick as well.  Using Google sheets with large datasets are no problem at all. * Backlit keyboard has a nice feel to it. * USB-C for power means I use my existing power adapters and not have to carry a proprietary cord around, or buy extras. * Having a traditional USB port is nice for connecting thumb drives without having to carry a USB-C adapter around.At first I missed an HDMI connector so I can hook it up to my monitor, but with two USB-C connectors I can use one of my docks if I want to, along with a keyboard and mouse.

review_title: awesome for casual use, low sound volume
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on March 27, 2022
review_text: I have a Smasung tablet S7+ and actually like this better when I am out and about. Battery lasts forever, system is very responsive. Only drawback is that the sound volume is very low. I have two, and this is consistent between them. It has a headphone jack, so I normally use headphones.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on November 27, 2021
review_text: We got this as a replacement Chromebook for an older Samsung unit that was getting older in age.  One thing that we noticed right off the bat was the screen size.  Because of the wider screen, there is more horizontal space but there's more vertical scrolling involved.The packaging, power adapter and overall appearance from unpacking was quite nice.  We did notice that the unit came 4G ready but that's not anything that we need at this time.  It's nice to know that it's there but it's not anything that made us purchase the unit in the first place.The battery life seems on par with a Chromebook.  All day usage.  The screen shows great color resolution and really is a nice improvement over our last unit, which was pretty nice already.We're not using the webcam, so I can't speak to that.  It's become the family workhorse desktop when we need to quickly research anything.

review_title: It pulls off being a laptop and a tablet in one, sufficiently!
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on December 24, 2021
review_text: It’s taken a bit of time to be able to gather enough information to write an informative review….For the most part, I use my computer for shopping, emails, and social media. I don’t do hardcore video or photo editing, or gaming.I found I get the best use of this computer while traveling. The battery life is remarkable! I’m able to download movies, books, and music for entertainment during those dreaded waits. All while being able to get some work done has well… Also, it is not heavy when packing.Overall, it’s a powerful computer that pulls off being a laptop and a tablet in one, sufficiently for my needs when not at home.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on October 11, 2021
review_text: This is a really good little device for web, email and media consumption. Chromebooks aren't going to be your 'workhorse' laptops but will let you do the things you need to do, including using Google Docs, Email, web browsing and consuming media.

review_title: Fumbles Badly on Zoom, Definitely Not Worth $800
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on October 14, 2021
review_text: --------UPDATE TO REVIEW, 10/16/21:--------I originally filed my 5-star review (shown below) on 10/14/21 without testing this Acer Chromebook PC on Zoom. I figured that any $800 name-brand PC released in 2021 could of course handle a Zoom call. Boy was I wrong.I attempted a six-way Zoom call on the afternoon of 10/16/21 using this Acer Chromebook and observed very poor performance. On my end, the incoming videos would often freeze for long periods (five to twenty seconds) and the incoming sound would also go silent for similar periods. On the other end of the Zoom call, the parties reported to me that my video would freeze for long periods, and my sound, when present, was often garbled and impossible to understand.I moved this Acer Chromebook to a position close to our WiFi router, in a different room, to check whether WiFi signal strength might be contributing to these Zoom problems. But the problems persisted.I disconnected this Acer Chromebook from the Zoom call and completed the Zoom call on the Lenovo Windows 10 laptop mentioned in the review below, which was located in the room where I had started the Zoom call on the Acer machine. With the help of an excellent outboard webcam, the Lenovo machine performed beautifully on the remainder of this Zoom call, in stark contrast to the Acer's very substandard and unacceptable performance.This Acer machine might still be an acceptable machine for other purposes, but if you think you might ever use Zoom, buy something else.--------ORIGINAL REVIEW, 10/14/21, under the headline "A Good PC, but Worth $800?":--------Perhaps no consumer product is as complicated as a PC. So it is essentially impossible for any PC maker to get every detail "perfect" in their products; indeed, it's not even clear what "perfect" means in this context.This is not a perfect PC, none are. If I could assign fractional stars, I'd probably deduct 0.2 stars from my rating for the issues discussed below, giving this PC 4.8 stars.This was the first Chromebook PC I have evaluated. Its setup was easy and based on your (free) Amazon Gmail account. This PC offers the option for an Enterprise Administration account, which was claimed to be free, but I didn't activate it as I could not see any use for it as an individual home user. Moreover, I wasn't even sure it was free in perpetuity based on the wording given in the Google website that the setup instructions directed me to.As for the features and vagaries of this PC, where to begin? Well, this laptop is impressively thin and lightweight. And the keyboard has a nice touch and feel, as laptop keyboards go. (I prefer connecting an outboard keyboard, but that's me.) The keyboard backlight feature would be useful in the dark, and it looks cool!The speakers for this PC sound weak and tinny—not even as good as my smartphone's speakers. Although bad speakers are typical for laptop and tablet PCs, these Acer PC speakers seem a little tinnier than average. Much more important, though, is that the headphone sound was excellent. For ear safety, I was glad that the sound volume control did not allow you to set it very high for headphones. I was able to set it plenty loud enough for my ears, but some users who like to blast their ears with headphone music (or who are hard of hearing on account of years of said ear blasting) might wish the headphone volume could be set louder.The screen was shiny, which can cause a problem with the reflection of room light sources. But that problem is not particular to this PC: All PCs I've evaluated have shiny screens. I wonder why they can't make PCs with touchscreens of low reflectivity, such as the screens used on Amazon Kindle devices.The camera on this PC is stunningly good, especially compared to the very poor cameras I've seen on various other laptop and tablet PCs I have evaluated. This Acer's camera seems to be fixed focus, but with an excellent depth of field stretching from about three inches to infinity. The color, detail, clarity, and contrast were all excellent, as was its ability to operate in both bright and dim light.And I was very pleased to discover that this PC's two microphones are used to create a true, sensitive stereo sound system of high quality. (This stands in contrast to another laptop I evaluated that used its two microphones to create not stereo, but a highly directional sound system that worked poorly, and it stands in stark contrast to virtually all outboard webcams I've evaluated, which claim to produce stereo sound but instead employ a single microphone to produce MONOx2.) The only fly in the ointment for this Acer Chromebook's microphone sound system was a faint, low-frequency rumble I could hear through my headphones on the video recordings I made with this PC. This rumble was not external electrical interference, as I detected it at constant strength in recordings made in various rooms of our house and also outdoors. The rumble is so soft that most users would probably not notice it and it would not interfere with using this PC for applications such as Zoom calls. This sound system will provide excellent pickup for a roomful of Zoom participants.I cut my teeth in the computing world on Linux/Unix, and I always install some Linux or Linux-like system on my PCs. As the Chromebook OS is strongly based on Linux, turning on Linux was super easy. It was just a couple of soft-button pushes and a few minutes to wait while the PC ground away. Once Linux was active, however, I immediately discovered that the gcc and g++ compilers were missing. This is likely not Acer's fault, but rather a deficiency in Google's Chromebook OS. After consulting web sources, I eventually found and installed the right deb files to fix this problem.I'm not a PC benchmarking expert and I had no intention of running a standard benchmarking suite on this PC, but I did compile and run a simple C program under Chromebook Linux that performed 20 billion integer multiplications. For comparison, I ran this same simple test on several Windows PCs, compiling the C code there under Cygwin. The running time results are interesting:Acer Chromebook, circa 2021, Qualcomm Kryo 468 Octa-core CPU (Up to 2.4 GHz): 62.5 secLenovo Windows 10 laptop, circa 2021, 11th Gen Intel(R) Core(TM) i3-1115G4 @ 3.00GHz (2 cores, 4 threads): 40.2 secDell Windows 10 Desktop, circa 2014, Intel(R) Pentium(R) CPU G3220 @ 3.00GHz (2 cores, 2 threads): 52.2 secAs can be seen above, the Acer Chromebook was slower than even my 2014-vintage Dell Windows desktop, and the Acer performed this task 55% slower than my Lenovo Windows laptop. Based on clock speeds, the slowdown should have been only 25%, not 55%. However, I don't mean to unfairly disparage the Acer over the results of such a rudimentary benchmark. The Acer's eight cores working together can undoubtedly do some amazing things that would advantage it in certain applications, such as gaming. (I did not evaluate the gaming performance of this PC.)On balance, I found much to like in this PC. I do wonder, though, whether it is worth the relatively high price of $800.

review_title: Good for the money. Great for school.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on May 25, 2024
review_text: In a whirlwind of tech shopping, I sought my ex-husband's counsel on which computer brand to snag. He's an Acer aficionado and had just snagged one for his biz. He flung a link my way to the very model he bagged. Mid-convo, I stumbled upon a beast with more RAM and storage than a digital warehouse - it was practically a gaming rig in disguise. So, I snagged it. A few weeks in, and it's a love affair with a minor hiccup - the caps lock is a ninja, stealthy and unseen, which I, the accidental samurai, strike all too often. The 10-key pad, squished like a sardine, turned out to be a decorative piece for a touch-typist like me. And the number lock? Also, a master of disguise. You'd think a backlit keyboard would flaunt an indicator or two, but nope. Miskeys are my new jam, but not a dealbreaker. Farewell, touchscreen, hello traditional keys - less memory hogging, more typing. Microsoft 11 S and I aren't buddies, but that's a story for another OS. For school or work? Thumbs up, with a wink for the quirks. (This is just me enjoying a bit of fun with Copilot. 😊)

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on December 24, 2023
review_text: This Acer laptop is my third attempt at a new computer.  The first two (different brands) were total frustration.  One advertised backlit keyboard, which it did not actually have.  Second one was advertised as "new" and "2023", but actually is a 2021 model, possibly refurbished.  But this is a beautiful machine, and so far has delivered on everything advertised. No touch screen, but it was not advertised as having one, and was not high on my list. The battery life is the only "negative" I've found so far, but since that had been mentioned in a number of reviews, it was not a surprise, and I can cope with that.  I'm getting a couple hours (3-4, maybe) on battery, which is manageable.  The backlit keyboard is awesome (only lit when in actual use, which conserves battery), and the feel of the keyboard layout and keys is very comfortable.  Screen is bright and sharp for a computer at this level.  Not sure I'll ever be good friends with Windows 11, but we are at least on speaking terms.  Processor is not the fastest available, but for spreadsheets, documents, photo editing, web surfing, etc, it has responded as quickly as hoped for Shipment was timely and packaging was sturdy and secure.  ACER documentation and registration is straightforward  I only dinged it on "value" because of the battery life -- this nice of a machine deserves a better battery. Otherwise, I am really happy with this.  Merry Christmas to me!EDIT:  did some research, made a couple of adjustments, and it has helped battery life, I think.  I'm currently at about 4 hours on battery, with about 60% battery life remaining.

review_text: This Acer laptop arrived three days ago -- a day before it was scheduled to -- and I have no complaints, to speak of, yet.  It is faster than any computer I have ever owned, though that isn't saying much. But it _is_ really fast.Folks have complained about the battery life. I suppose it depends on what you use it for-- me, I'm not a gamer.  My old Aspire 1 didn't have a strong battery, but I think this model has a better one.  I can certainly get more than three hours from it without a charge (though I can't imagine when I would ever be using this computer for more than three hours without access to an outlet --I'm an old white guy for whom, for instance, typing away on the beach for more than three hours would be a major skin-cancer risk, and doing so on a plane would make me air-sick).I have some concern, too, about the provenance of this computer. Apparently, it has been upgraded by the the seller, which may mean it has no warranty that Acer would honor. review_title: Very Nice Laptop, Especially for the Price
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on October 6, 2023
review_text: Upgraded from my 2019 Lenovo to this one. Quite the improvement! Start up time is really good, about ten seconds until it’s ready for the password and another twenty or so until it’s ready for use — less than 30 seconds to boot up. I got the 20 GB of RAM and 1 TB of SSD storage option. The dual-core-dual-thread processor is plenty powerful for what I need it for. Picture quality it nice and sharp. On a full charge, battery life seems to be about 7 hours with the screen on half brightness. It comes with a six foot cord, so I rarely use it without it being plugged in somewhere. For less than $400 including tax, I’m quite impressed with this little laptop. Of course, I’m not mining Bitcoin with it, but if you’re like me and would describe your laptop use as fairly average, I can’t recommend it enough.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on January 6, 2024
review_text: I’m not super tech savvy when it comes to the operating system of computers so this may seem silly to some.  I got the computer and the first thing I wanted to do was load my Norton antivirus protection on it. Two hours and the help from Norton Tech support later, it was finally done.  Every time I tried to load the program I got a message that it was not compatible with the windows program I had on the computer and that I needed to download the app first. Followed those instructions but it still didn’t appear to be loaded.  After waiting a lifetime for Norton tech support i finally got it loaded. While watching them work on the computer I noticed that they turned off S Mode on my computer, which I didn’t know you could do. So if anyone is having difficulty loading programs, that may be the cause.  Other than that I like the laptop. It’s is small and light and seems to run fine so far.

I do wish the power supply plugged in either on the back or on the right instead of the left, but all laptops seem to be like that for some reason. It was easy to get started with it, and so far, I've had no issues other than Windows 11 issues and that's a Microsoft thing, not a Lenovo thing. It's very fast, especially compared to my old computer, and I believe the 20 GB RAM should keep it that way. So far, I've downloaded and installed no apps or software. I did take it out of S mode if/when I do want to install something that isn't in the Microsoft store. It's very light and seems to hold a charge well. Hopefully, the battery will last longer than the last two I put in the old computer.

review_title: Several issues to be aware of
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on December 22, 2023
review_text: I wasn't impressed with this laptop despite the mostly good reviews here. Here's the several issues I ran into.(1) Screen quality subpar - I'm not an expert in describing this stuff, but if you aren't directly in front of the screen, viewing quality diminishes considerably. It's also not very bright, nor is it clear.(2) Battery - for me it just drained quickly. I didn't do performance tests,  but I would basically work for a couple hours on light computing to see it drained about 40 percent from new. Imagine how it will do in a year or two?(3) Lenovo service and glitches with Windows - Windows currently doesn't allow the download of most browsers including Chrome unless you turn off something called "S-mode". It appears a BIOS update from Lenovo made it impossible for me to turn off S-mode and they offered no service when I contacted them unless I paid for premium support. The issue was their BIOS, but they didn't care, no service from them unless you pay.(4) Cheap feel - Unlike my current, and fairly ancient, HP Pavilion x360 purchased in 2016, everything feels like thin plastic on the Lenovo whereas my HP has lots of metal and more robust plastics. Yes, the Lenovo weighs less, but that's not going to help anyone when you drop it on the floor which will inevitably happen on occasion.Hard pass. Amazon reviews often are lacking, and I don't write many, but given the downsides, I wanted to speak up on this on.  Think carefully and test carefully before settling on this laptop.

The computer that I received does match the picture on Amazon so I should have checked that out before buying without relying on the name. The computer, for what it is, is working fine and I have no desire to return yet another Lenova; the first one I was sent had the wrong processor. review_title: A Great Value and Very Capable Laptop
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on November 4, 2023
review_text: Right out of the box, this laptop has impressed.  Setup was very easy through mostly automation.  Having One Drive ensured that all of my existing applications and settings from my old laptop transferred over seamlessly.  The 20GB memory and 2TB HD is a powerhouse compared to my previous Dell.  The case is solid but light,  The screen resolution is vivid.  Start up time is about 20 seconds.  With 3 USB and one HDMI she is capable although I wish it had an ethernet, I am more that happy.  Shipping was two days and it was packed well in original OEM packaging.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on August 6, 2022
review_text: This is a great laptop. I bout the 1TB HD because I wanted plenty of space and never have to worry. I use this laptop for business and it's perfect. It's very fast and loads programs with ease. It has backlighting on keys which makes the keys much more visible in darker spaces. I have not tried gaming, but I think it would perform pretty average, after all, it isn't designed for that.Windows 11 is nicer and I was quite surprised how much I like it. I'm an old fan of Windows 7. Some of the features with navigation are still a bit more intuitive to find but all in all am pretty happy with the 11 interface.I run office 2010 on this and of course Windows constantly reminds me it's not supported. Whatever Microflop!All in all this is a very nice laptop and a much needed addition to my business management. Battery life seems about 8 hours off charger which is pretty poor but I rarely travel with this so it stays on the charger. For anyone wanting a good price point for a computer with good hard drive space, this is a nice choice!

review_title: This item was out of warranty before I purchased it.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on June 14, 2023
review_text: We have had this laptop for almost a year and now have hardware issues with it- repeated BSOD's due to a harddrive failure.  Lenovo's warranty is one year but according to them it was out of warranty prior to our purchase of the item.  We have tried to contact the seller - there voicemail is full and they have not responded to the message we sent them.  Amazons support tells me that because has been 10-11 months they do not care that the seller is selling items like this and recommended that I contact Lenovo again who again says we are out of warranty.  BEWARE you maybe getting a used laptop and do not expect support from PCOnline or Amazon as they do not care and told me there is nothing they can do!  I will report back if we get any assistance with this item.  Next time we will purchase from a reputable seller.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on August 7, 2022
review_text: First, this is listed on Amazon as Windows 10 and it comes with Windows 11 so some updating in the description is needed. Not complaining - just sayin'...I needed a quick emergency laptop so ordered this one to use for a few days and as a future backup computer while my huge desktop was in for repair. I am a graphic artist so the only software I could use efficiently on this laptop is the installed MS Office which was no surprise. But what was a surprise is that when I tried to upgrade the MS Office to my business account and also tried to install a browser other than Edge - it slowed down the system considerably.So I'm resetting it to factory settings and using only the Edge browser because as a back up unit for emergencies - I can use the home version of MS Office. I usually only use PowerPoint anyway and for temporary use - the Home version is fine!But now that I understand the limitations along with the other nice features such as touch screen and Windows 11 security features, I'm happy to keep this as a second option in my office that I can use for online only marketing purposes and for my grandson to be able to access his email for classes, etc.The pink color is very nice, by the way, as my office is in pinks, greens, and blacks. So, for what it's built for - it's a very nice option and works great. I definitely recommend that other people try it out!

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on April 17, 2024
review_text: After unpacking this laptop, I looked and scrutinized the whole unit. I was very impressed, because this refurbished model looked brand new! No scratches, No dents, extremely clean!The setup of windows 10 Pro was a breeze, even the 10 G network over Thunderbolt was / is extremely fast. The i7 CPU, 16 Gb Ram, and Thunderbolt work together extremely well. It only took a few minutes to get "everything" set up. After imaging the drive to my NAS for safety reasons, I upgraded to Windows 11 Pro. Now I'm even more impressed! Absolutely error free upgrade to Windows 11 Pro. I'm using a Sonnettech Solo 10 G SFP+ Thunderbolt connection and it is crazy FAST. Reinstalling my software went through error free and really quick. I can definitely recommend this seller and would definitely buy from them again. I definitely feel that I purchased a very good refurbished laptop. Naturally, the 14" screen is too small for me, but the HDMI port connects to a 27" Samsung curved monitor which is perfect for me. Having a USB 3.1 hub with 3 ports helps when connection ports are limited. I did notice that 3 keys on the keyboard needed a little TLC because they wouldn't respond 100% correct, but after Q-tip cleaning they worked as designed 😉.I'm very surprised and happy with this purchase!One month update:I have put this laptop through the paces of rigorous office work and high speed network compatibility using a 10 Gb SFP+ Thunderbolt connection. This is awesome!It works flawlessly on my 10 Gb network and can do a complete laptop NVMe drive image in under 7 minutes. Even after the update to Windows  11 Pro the system is running great.If you need a reliable and fast laptop, then check out this seller, good quality and fast delivery, but hurry, they are selling out fast!

review_title: Local Admin Password Locked Down - Cannot Make Changes to The COMPUTER!
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on September 25, 2023
review_text: The laptop overall is great for the price.The problem is that when I turned on the laptop it automatically logged into the desktop with the local admin account. Of course, I do not have the password which means that I cannot create my own local admin account. When trying to create my own local account I am prompted for the current password which is not possible. This is not acceptable and is not a proper Windows Image. A proper Windows Image for resale has the computer defaulted to first time login and you are able to login and create your own account or login with a Microsoft account.I should not and will not argue with the seller regarding his business practices.I simply returned the item and get my money back.For this reason, only (which is a very important issue); I am super disappointed with this purchase.I am an IT Professional so please believe me, that the computers should have a professional Windows Image with first time login available to the new user.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on May 16, 2024
review_text: This is one of the best laptops for the price on the market. It is faster than other laptops at this price point and has good screen quality and battery life. The SSD is small but is easy enough to add additional storage. 8GB of RAM is also not enough for many intense applications, but it is still a great deal for the money. However, there is some bloatware that you should remove when setting up this laptop, though that is unfortunately the standard in this industry. Other than that, I would absolutely recommend this laptop for its great value.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on January 2, 2024
review_text: The Acer Aspire 5 A515-56-347N Slim Laptop has proven to be a great choice for our son's high school needs. The 15.6" Full HD IPS display provides a clear and vibrant visual experience, while the 11th Gen Intel i3-1115G4 Dual Core Processor ensures smooth performance for various tasks. The 8GB DDR4 RAM and 128GB NVMe SSD contribute to quick and efficient multitasking and fast storage access. The inclusion of WiFi 6 and Amazon Alexa adds modern connectivity and convenience features. The fact that it comes with Windows 11 Home in S Mode is a nice touch. Overall, this laptop offers a solid combination of performance and features, making it well-suited for high school use. Highly recommended for students in need of a reliable and capable laptop.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on September 3, 2023
review_text: Update #2:  After about a year of use, still love it.  For those saying the 128GB SSD  is too small, simply add a 1 TB SSD or old HDD as I did (d: drive) in the available motherboard slot for your apps, games movies, etc.).  I did add 4gb of additional ram (now has 12gb) since I had it laying around, but it really didn't need it - ran fine with 8gb.One negative:  Who ever designed the power port should be fired.  It's a 1/8" jack and not robust at all.  I hit the cable the wrong way and it goes into batter mode.  The jack is a piece of crap and should have been made bigger (like a USB size or 1/4").Follow my instructions below to clean up the OS, etc. and this thing runs like a champ...Update:(After several months of using): Love it!  Solid as a rock.  It is what it is. A.K.A. Not necessarily the best components (you get what you pay for) but if you know what you're doing (to clean it up), Delete S mode, add a secondary SDD or HDD drive (in my case an old 1 TB HDD), 4 or 8 GB additional RAM (doesn't really need it, delete all the bloatware, disable the items in startup, tighten up all the privacy settings, etc., this thing runs great (everything including sound (some people seem to have issues - but mine's fine).  Not heating up, no slowing down.  Bargain for what you get...-----------------------------------------------Purchased this to replace on older Acer laptop (which is going to the wife to replace her older POS HP). Originally wanted an Acer with a backlit keyboard (like my current one has) but Amazon couldn't seem to send me the correct laptop (twice), so I opted for this one (good price, decent CPU, and 8 GB RAM installed).Went with ACER since I'm happy with my current one, plus it allows you to add more memory, upgrade the NVMe SSD, and an an additional SDD / HDD (which I plan to do.  The 8GB of RAM seems to be doing fine but I haven't really pushed it yet.  The NVMe SSD is half full, but once I install the 1TB HDD from my old laptop I'll load any new programs, music, etc. on that.  This laptop is what it is.  Not high end, and not as solid as my old Acer (keyboard not as solid, etc.) but it's fine so far (except I wish it had a backlit keyboard - miss that).  * Task manager indicates that only one of the two slots are being used by the 8GB RAM (I thought they may have added 4 GB in the 2nd slot to bring it up to 8GB), so, if that's the case, I may add an additional 8GB in the 2nd slot (good idea to add the same size RAM in the 2nd slot, but not absolutely necessary).I had the intent of downgrading to Windows 10 since that's what I'm use to, but decided to stay with Windows 11.  It took a few hours to get used to 11 but in fact, it's not much different then 10 once you get things set up how you want it.  I immediately disabled unwanted apps under task manager startup, deleted unwanted apps (lots of Microsoft crap, and others), turned off S mode, turned off all privacy settings (disabled all the privacy settings that were turned on), and other tweaks.  You can Google "how to make Windows 11 faster" for a start for recommended settings / tweaks.  The sound's a bit weak but good enough (speakers are pretty much crap, but what do you expect in a laptop).  There's not much for color / display adjustment, and certain screens look a bit washed out, while others are very vivid (youtube 4K/8K videos look great).  Trackpad works fine (can't stand the tap feature but that can be turned off under the touchpad settings.  Some people report that the laptop gets hot and the fan blows (and is loud) because of that.  I have not seen any indication of that yet (and I hope I don't.  My wife's HP gets extremely hot and the fan is constantly blowing, and I hate it, so I'm relieved that this one is not like that (so far).For the price, and if all you plan to do is surf the Web, check email, stream videos, etc., I highly recommend this laptop.  *  So far, so good...

review_title: Zippy lightweight laptop, excellent for the price!
