review_title: Good for the money, with some pronounced limitations
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on December 4, 2020
review_text: Further Update 4-5-2021: At the current price of $748, I think you can do better than this. I spent about that much including an additional 16MB RAM, for a total of 24MB, and an additional 1TB SSD. But I'm happy I got it and if the price drops back down to around what I paid before the upgrades, $599, it still seems like a good deal.UPDATE 3-24-2021: I had to send my desktop unit in for repair about a month ago. That took about two weeks because it got stuck in transit when Texas got closed down by bad weather, and I had to use the laptop as my primary computer during that time. I connected it to my graphics monitor via the HDMI port, plugged a powered USB hub running four external hard drives, my graphics tablet and my webcam into one USB port, and used the other two USB ports for a card reader and wireless mouse. So, pretty much maxed out all the connectivity options including the ethernet port. Obviously I was not running all this off the battery.Other than time-wasting, I mostly use the computer for photo editing. The images are from a full-frame camera so the files are quite large to start and I often enlarge them. Editing uses a lot of memory and CPU/GPU juice. I had added 16GB of memory when I got the machine, which came in handy.  As one would expect, the laptop didn't perform as well as the souped-up desktop does: everything took longer and it got frustrating at times. I wished I had added a larger SSD, which I've now done (another $100, bringing the total including the additional memory up to about $750). Ultimately, though, I got everything done that needed doing and I'm still impressed with the machine. It may be outdated already, I haven't looked, but I'm happy with the purchase and it definitely kept me sane while the desktop was gone, which my old laptop would not have done.This is a preliminary review of the Nitro 5 with the 9th Gen Intel Core i5-9300H and the NVIDIA GeForce GTX 1650. I've had the machine for two weeks now. I paid $600 and dropped an additional $50 on a 16gb RAM stick, for a total of 24gb. I bought it because it was the least expensive unit I could find with a discrete GPU. I wanted something I can use for basic photo editing when I travel or when I feel like sitting in a cafe for a while, because I'm an optimist who believes both those things will be routine again some day. I'm not a gamer and can't speak to its capabilities for that.First the things I don't like:1) the keyboard. The keys are serviceable but a bit mushy. I prefer a more clicky keyboard but that's really a matter of taste and not function, and after two weeks I've adjusted to it. It's a good size, not cramped, and has a full-sized numerical pad. What I really don't like is that it's basically unusable in the daytime without the backlight turned up most of the way, and the backlight goes off when you pause typing for a few seconds, presumably to save battery. I don't understand that design decision. If you really want to save battery, make a keyboard that you can see without the backlight on. And the shift functions on the keys don't stand out that well even with the backlight. Maybe it's a gaming aesthetic thing, but I don't like it.2) The touchpad. It's just not very accurate. Moving between open tabs on a browser or trying to select tools in Photoshop or Lightroom and related plugins is a pain. I just use a mouse. I don't know what gamers use touchpads for but I can't imagine they'd like this one very well.3) Battery life. With the GPU idle, just using the unit for browsing, email and some writing, I got a bit more than five hours on a charge. When I started doing some moderately intensive photo editing involving the GPU, battery life dropped dramatically. If you're doing anything CPU/GPU intensive for any length of time you'll most likely want to keep it plugged in.4) Webcam. If I'm home I'm using my desktop webcam, and if I'm out I'm using my phone. The one on the unit is sort of a disaster. I guess that's where they're saving money. I would think anybody using the computer for Zoom or to stream would want to use an external USB one.5) Weight. This is a chonky fellow. I took it in my camera backpack on a shoot involving a lot of walking and noticed the extra couple pounds over the laptop it replaced. Not a big issue, though.6) Audio. The speakers are muddy and weak. You'll want to use headphones for music or gaming. It comes with Waves Maxx Audio, which I use on my desktop, but no amount of equalizing or enhancing is going to save these speakers. I expect nothing from laptop audio in this price range, and I got it.The keyboard backlight is the most aggravating of all those concerns for me. Classic example of form over function. Battery life is second, the touchpad third, and the webcam fourth. None of the issues come close to being deal breakers.Things I like:1) Performance. This is a $600 laptop with a decent four-core processor and a discrete GPU. Would I like an i7 or better and the RTX 2060? Sure. Do I want to pay another $500 or more for them? Why no: no I do not. It moved along pretty well right out of the box, and  and with the inexpensive RAM upgrade it positively zips. Again, I can't speak to the gaming capabilities, but I'm really pleased with the performance for my needs. I'll have to add some storage at some point, as I expect many people will, but that's pretty inexpensive these days too.2) Construction: as the weight would indicate, this thing is solid. Despite the plastic body, nothing about it feels cheap. There's not much flex to the screen. The only thing I don't like about it is that the back is a solid piece that has to be completely removed to upgrade the RAM or the drives. It'd be nice if it had access panels for those. Prying it apart was anxiety-inducing. You should note there's an included SSD cable but it's not installed and it's tiny so put it somewhere safe and install it the first time you have the back off.3) The screen. I was quite pleasantly surprised by the brightness and accuracy. I did some work on a few pics that I then looked at on my graphics monitor, which cost more than this machine, and the colors were pretty much right on. I can't speak to it for gaming purposes, the frame/refresh rate is more or less irrelevant to me, but it's better than I expected for what I'm doing with it.4) Heat management. This is exceptional. The chassis is built to dissipate heat, and the two fans work really well, independently of one another, and quietly. Acer provides a heat management utility that allows the user to manually control the fans and to keep track of the processor temperatures. I've used the laptop as an actual laptop for up to two hours without appreciable discomfort.5) Bloatware. There's hardly any, and the Acer utilities are actually useful. I had to get rid of the preinstalled Norton Security and Microsoft Office trials but that's an easy job.6) Appearance. It's fine. It has the sort of angular, aggressive styling that seems to be de rigueur for gaming, and in this instance the styling incorporates the heat dissipation features so it's functional as well. I'd prefer something other than black but it's fine.7) Ports. It has an HDMI out, 2 USB 3.0, a USB-C, a USB 2.0, an ethernet port, an earphone jack and of course a power input. Pretty good collection. You can get by without Thunderbolt ports.tl;dr: As you would expect from a machine at this price point, Acer made some compromises. The camera and speakers are subpar, and the unit is mostly plastic. They also made some design decisions that are borderline incomprehensible to me, as with the keys not showing up well in good light without the backlight. The heat handling is great, the screen performance is better than I expected, it's fast and powerful, and I'm still surprised at getting even an entry-level GPU at this price. For a non-gamer using it as a photo editing and general purpose laptop, the value seems exceptional.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on October 19, 2020
review_text: I really enjoy this laptop, It's super quick. Loads into windows under 4 seconds.I added a "Kingston Technology HyperX Impact 8GB 2666MHz DDR4 CL15 260-Pin SODIMM Laptop Memory (HX426S15IB2/8)" ram module for making the Ram 16GB total, this will work best with the shared GPU memory.YOU WILL NEED MORE RAM FOR HEAVIER GAMESThe onboard GPU memory is shared with your ram when in gaming mode.I played space engineers, which requires around 5GB of VRAM for medium gameplay, it leaked into my actual ram, but with the hyperx upgrade there was only slight FPS drops but not enough to affect gameplay. Ram is important.I recommend windows 10 Pro 1909, don't use 2004 on this laptop will die really quick in Win 10 2004. Lasted about 3 hours under full load, whist 1909 lasted around 7 hours under full load, close to expected battery life.The Intel CPU Turbos to 3.98 Ghz while plugged in, if you set it that way.If you plan to install linux, the NVME will not be detected at boot time, to fix this, head to bios and on the first tab or second tab press "CTRL" + "S" to bring up a setting and change and disable intel optane firmware to use nvme in linux, as when you boot a non windows OS, the nvme will be placed into sleep mode.As for a extra nvme slot, i picked up "Western Digital 250GB WD Blue SN550 NVMe Internal SSD - Gen3 x4 PCIe 8Gb/s, M.2 2280, 3D NAND, Up to 2,400 MB/s - WDS250G2B0C" from many other users, as this will take full advantage of the laptops firmware and hardware. You can pick higher space storage, but as a light gamer, this was enough for me.As for the 2.5" drive, i picked up a "ST1000LM024 HN-m101Mbb" It's a 1TB Mechanical Drive with decent write and read speeds for lighter games, and game storage. Granted it is slower, but for this laptop its perfect and I can get full R/W speeds that were advertised. If you notice, it's the same drive inside the XBox 1 - 1st Gen, so You can game on it as well, not as fast load times, but its fast enough to still enjoy a game.Besides the battery life, this is a really good laptop if you go out to a friends house for a night and do some moderate gaming like a LAN party, or a small road trip, or sitting out side for a few hours.I do not recommend taking this on a flight. Unless you get an extra battery.As of this message, I am using this as my main pc, and quite enjoy it, the Intel i5v9 is great and the GTX 1650 plays most games on Medium/High at 50/60fps.Also another note to stay on 1909, is that windows f--ked up the NVIDIA auto select method for Intel Graphics and GPU graphics, so some games will default to intel CPU instead of NVIDIA.Also, This laptop can play COD: Cold War at High settings with 48/55fps under heavy scenes and a perfect 60fps on normal fighting.

review_title: Hefty but Heroic! A real Gamer’s laptop
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on January 15, 2021
review_text: This is the first gaming laptop I ever owned, although I have owned about 6 other laptops previously. This is a great gaming platform with just a few cons.First, the Pros: Nice sized display with high resolution and a clear, bright display. Sound is incredible in quality, although the volume is very low. Keyboard is crispy, and the backlight can be dimmed or brightened or turned off. Touchpad is responsive although I prefer to use a wireless mouse instead. WIFI has a good strong signal and connections are quick and reliable. Plenty of ports, and built-in cooler makes this a well rounded player. Upgrades are easy to do, and with 2 NVME slots plus a 2.5 drive slot, you won’t be hurting for storage space. The memory can be upgraded to 32GB if you need it.CONS: just a few, and none are deal breakers for me. The first is the weight. Not sure what it is, but this is no lightweight. It’s hefty!! Second, Acer went for some fancy design with the case that has the corners chopped diagonally. It’s not actually sharp, but it can be a bit pokey if you’re balancing it with one hand on your knee while battling behemoths in Dauntless. That’s pretty much all I could find to say negatively.All in all, this is a great laptop at a reasonable price for the specs. It will definitely stand up to whatever you can dish out in your favorite games.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on June 11, 2023
review_text: I purchased the i5- 9300H Version with a GTX 1650 and 8 GB RAM. Out of the box this Laptop isn't the best unfortunately, so expect to have to spend a little extra to get it to feel like a gaming machine.After upgrading up to 16 GB of RAM I immediately noticed a massive difference in power. Going from nearly unplayable to 60-80 FPS in most games on Medium to High settings. Even some AAA games that came out recently can be played on this including Hogwarts Legacy, Dead Space Remake, and I even managed to get Far Cry 6 and Cyberpunk to run on this (Far Cry got 50-60 FPS and Cyberpunk got 40-50 FPS.I will say a big concern were the temps. The temps ranged between 90- 104 Celsius at times. This can be fixed with software that under-volts your CPU but make sure to watch plenty of YouTube videos if you are unfamiliar with that type of thing. After doing this myself my temps don't go above 65 even in intense games. I also recommend Laptop cooling pads, in my review image you see my laptop sitting on one, They help push a lot of hot air out from under the laptop.All in all this is a very solid purchase and its a fast little machine that does its job. Just keep in mind you'll need to upgrade it if you want to use it at its fullest capabilities.

review_title: Its decent, but just to hot to handle.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on September 22, 2020
review_text: First of all  the performance is great for any game you want to play, however, not all games can run at 60 fps on the highest graphics. For example, Doom Eternal can run perfectly and stay at 60 fps on medium graphics.  That's actually saying a lot considering doom is a very demanding game.  Anything higher than medium will go past the 4gb vram limit. Now the big problem is the throttling. Yes this laptop's CPU can hit 4.1 GHz, that doesn't mean it can control the heat emitting from such power. I mean seriously, even at start up it would hit the 80* C range, the highest and scariest temp it has gotten to was 90* C!!!  At that temp the computer is basically killing itself. The fans do some good work but without a cooling pad it just cant get the airflow it needs. Even with the cooling pad its still in the 80* C range. So, This is what i did to fix it from throttling and keep it running cool and efficient (cooler temps mean better performance) I downloaded a application known as Throttle Stop, it is well known and trusted, HOWEVER it is VERY dangerous if you don't know what you doing. All i did was simply turn the GHz  multiplier down to 33 (this means the CPU runs at 3.30 GHz)  and then adjusted the Mv (millivolts) to -168Mv this is the magic number for me, now the CPU runs no hotter than 70* C, when playing arma 3 anyway. I have tried other demanding games and it seems to still throttle unfortunately, the next best thing is to limit the max power going to the CPU, to 99% this is done in the power management settings on windows. This is much safer, however, it makes the CPU run at 2.40 MHz (the base MHz) this will run cool! But it bottlenecks so much and just takes away the capability this computer has. So Final conclusion... This thing is literally to hot to handle, If the airflow and thermal paste were better it would run fine at 4.1 MHz but its just not. If your a tech person you could always reapply some better thermal paste but no telling if that would work better or not. Honestly tho, for this price, its OK. Just keep in mind that if you do get it, do not run it at 4.1 MHz. AND DO NOT TRY AND OVERCLOCK ANYTHING YOU WILL KILL IT AS IT IS ALREADY DYING OUT OF THE BOX.

review_title: Fully compatible with Linux, serves as Pi-hole DNS server and backup PC
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on August 11, 2023
review_text: Besides my new, bold red laptop, there were a few items inside the box. I found a small, black wired USB mouse, a white charging adapter, a clear, washable keyboard protector and a short user manual.The laptop is thin and weighs below 4 pounds. It has four rubberized feet in each corner at the bottom side that slightly elevate it, so air can circulate beneath. The keyboard is red as well with white characters, has a keypad and many functions have to be called with the Fn button. However, it does have its own Volume control buttons. What I miss is lights for the keys. Yet, it has three indicator lights right above the keyboard on the left for Power On, Caps Lock and Num Lock.The touchpad is large and has a different tone of red. It makes a click sound when I press on it. It supports multThe 16 inch display has a resolution of 1920×1200. Its aspect ratio is 16:10, which is slightly wider than 16:9 but it’s a difference I can notice, especially when I’m working with office apps. I can tilt the screen up to 180 degrees. I find the colors are displayed accurately and lively. I can set the brightness with my keyboard or through the operating system.There are seven ports in total. On the right side are three ports: one USB 3.0, one headphone jack, on SD card slot. What I find curious is that there’s a small rectangular opening. I thought that would be another port but I couldn’t find any reference in the user manual. Yet, in the listing itself I could find a picture that labels it as lock but I could not find any more information on how to use that lock and what it actually locks. Maybe somebody can tell. Anyway, on the left side, there are four ports: again one USB 3.0, DC power, HDMI, and a type C USB port.On the bottom, I have quick access to the 512 GB SSD and HDD bay. With quick access I mean I don’t have to open up the whole laptop. I just have to unscrew to screws to remove the cover of the SSD; the same goes for the HDD bay.That said, I added a 2.5 inch 320 GB Seagate Hard Drive to the laptop and installed Debian 12 Bookworm. The installation of the second operating system went through without errors and I could boot into my new Linux OS in seconds. I encountered no hardware compatibility issues.By the way, secure boot was off by default and I haven’t changed anything in the BIOS which has been released by AMI on March 29, 2023.I also booted into the pre-installed OS, which is Windows 11. The first boot took long because I had to go through the first time setup and in the beginning, browsing wasn’t fast because Windows downloaded tons of updates. Yet, after the update, web browsing got back to normal.When I opened the task manager, I checked the performance tab and indeed, the laptop has 12 GB installed. However, what baffled me was that task manager listed open RAM slots. So, I opened up the command prompt and issued the following command: wmic memphysical get MaxCapacity. That told me the maximum RAM capacity the laptop can handle. I don’t remember the exact number but it was over 12 GB. So, I decided to open up the laptop to just find out there were no empty memory slots and the pre-installed memory is soldered together. In short, no way to add more RAM. Still, the RAM is decent enough for daily work. It’s 12 GB DDR4 SDRAM at 2400 Mhz.When I opened up the laptop, I could also see that it has a 38 watts battery. Fully charged, the battery lasts me slightly over six hours with a few applications open and viewing a few videos.The processor is an Intel Celeron Processor N5095 that was released in the first quarter of 2021 according to Intel’s website. I can do basic tasks like web browsing, email, office like powerpoint with it. It has four cores and can boost up to 2.9 GHz, which is enough power for most everyday tasks.When it comes to sound, the audio is ok as there are two speakers for stereo. However, I prefer to use my headset as I like to listen to songs at high volume. The built-in microphone captures sound clearly but I often end up using my headset’s mic but in either case, I can’t tell much difference. Recordings from both sound almost identical.The webcam’s resolution is ok but my face appears paler than in real life and movements show up slightly delayed. It’s also not compatible with Windows Hello’s face unlock feature. However, I don’t care as I will primarily use the laptop with Debian and rarely, if ever, use Windows.The laptop also has Bluetooth 4.2. I could pair it to my soundbar that I mainly use for my smart TV. I didn’t encounter any delays.I was able to connect my laptop to my home network using both 5G and 2.4G Wi-Fi. Even though it does not have an Ethernet port built-in, it instantly detected my USB-C hub with Ethernet. This is important to me because I use the laptop as a private Pi-hole DNS server. A Pi-hole is a network-wide ad blocker that blocks ads on all devices on my home network.A wired connection is important for a Pi-hole DNS server because it provides a more reliable and faster connection than Wi-Fi. Wi-Fi connections can be unreliable, especially in a crowded area or if there is interference from other devices. A wired connection is less likely to be interrupted, which means that my Pi-hole DNS server will be able to block ads more consistently. In addition, a wired connection can provide a faster connection, which is important for a Pi-hole DNS server because it needs to be able to quickly respond to DNS requests. If my Pi-hole DNS server is not able to respond quickly, then I may experience delays when loading websites.In addition to being more reliable and faster, a wired connection also uses less power than Wi-Fi. This is important because my laptop is now running a Pi-hole DNS server, which requires more resources than a normal laptop. By using a wired connection, I can save power and extend the battery life of my laptop.I have configured my Debian OS so that my laptop never turns off automatically. If it runs on battery due to a power outage, I have it set to turn off when the battery level reaches 5%. Furthermore, my laptop now boots directly into shell, no GUI at all. This saves even more resources.However, in case I need to use my laptop for work, I can quickly switch back to Debian's graphical interface. The Pi-hole DNS server can keep working while I'm using the laptop as with 12 GB RAM, it's more than enough to prevent it from running out of memory.

review_title: Great Laptop for The Price w/only two real flaws
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on November 8, 2023
review_text: This laptop is great. Great value for the cost! The size is good, not too heavy, bright screen and great picture. Good battery life. Fast internet browsing with multiple tabs and has never crashed. Track pad works great! Fast program downloads. I wish the keyboard lit up, but it's only an issue in certain lighting. One issue I have is that the sound is terrible. It hurt my ears because it's so metallic. I don't even use it without headphones. May just be an issue with my individual laptop, but due to school, I can't send it back in to get fixed or replaced. Secondly, the laptop charger is an issue. It takes a universal charger and the wiring gets loose very easily and stops charging. I have dogs who bump into me and I'm already on my 3rd charger in 5-6 months.  I'd blame the dogs, but I've had other chargers last years despite the pups.  Overall, if the sound issue was resolved I'd absolutely love this laptop and just deal with the charger issue.

review_title: A Great PC Laptop for the Money. Very Fast.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on June 27, 2023
review_text: I bought the AOCWEI laptop at the beginning of last week and it arrived promptly the next day. I was very pleased at the price being so reasonable but was very interested in seeing if it would live up to the specifications that were listed for it.So far, it has been performing very well. As I already mentioned it is very fast. I know that solid state hard drives are much faster than their mechanical predecessors but this exceeded my expectations. It boots up into Windows 11 in about 14-16 seconds from being totally turned off. Various items load and folders open very quickly. It is a joy to operate from that perspective alone.The screen resolution is very good and more than adequate for my needs. For the average person that needs a solid PC that performs very well and is well built, this is an amazing fit for a modest budget. It is nice and thin, and feels very solid to hold. It is more than adequate with standard USB and USB-C ports as well as an SD card slot to expand your storage. There is also a headphone jack that is compatible with commonly available ear buds and all of these various ports are well-identified on the bottom of the laptop.This is my first experience with Windows 11 and I was pleased that it came already installed on this laptop. It was easy to set up and I am finding it to be interesting but not difficult to use after having been used to Windows 10 for so long.The warranty on this machine is probably the best I have seen for a PC laptop. I hope that I never have to use it but it is nice to know that it has a lifetime warranty available. I had to look twice when I saw that, just to be sure my eyes were not deceiving me.All in all, if you have only a modest budget, I think that you would be hard-pressed to find any other laptop that is this solid, with the memory and storage that this one has, and that performs as well as this one does for the same or less money.

The screen resolution n overall graphics display quality is very good.  I am not an expert in that area, but it certainly meets my needs.The laptop itself is nice and thin and is very solid to hold.  It seems to  well built.  It has all the necessary standard USB, USB-C SD card and audio ports as well as a port for the power plug.It comes standard with Windows 11 and after having used Windows 10 for so long, I was surprised at how easy it was to adapt to Windows 11.  There are some features in Windows 11 that I Iike a lot, such as the ability to pen multiple tabs in windows explorer folders.This is the laptop I needed  It is very easy to carry sine it i nice and slim and does not weigh a ton.  It has a good-sized  SSD drive an enough RAM to do the job.  I needed something decent without a hefty price tag, and this was a good choice that fit the bill for me.

review_title: Great laptop for my everyday tasks.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on September 25, 2023
review_text: I like this laptop because it came with the Celeron Intel N5095 processor with its 4-core configuration, it delivers seamless and smooth performance for my everyday tasks.Whether I am browsing the web, working on documents, or even watching some videos, this laptop handles it all effortlessly. Its processor can reach speeds up to 2.9GHz ensuring that I can finish my tasks quickly and efficiently.Additionally, this laptop has a 1920 x 1200 2K screen and although it isn’t 4K, it still delivers clear and well-defined images, which is good enough for me since I am mainly using this laptop for basic tasks and to watch videos.In addition, this laptop can support dual Wi-Fi, so I can be connected to two different networks simultaneously which I appreciate.Furthermore, this laptop came with 12GB RAM and 512GB SSD of storage, and it can be expanded up to 1TB SSD or 2.5” HDD.However, since I am not a gamer and neither am I using this laptop for heavy-duty work, I currently don’t need a laptop with an extremely powerful processor and way more RAM.Because I am using this laptop mainly to browse the internet, check on my social media accounts, and watching videos so this laptop fits my needs.I like that this laptop has a cooling fan, which keeps my device running smoothly even after I have been using it for many hours.Although the laptop has built-in 12GB RAM and 512GB SSD storage space, it can support up to 1TB SSD expansion, making this laptop more than capable of handling multi-application and multimedia workflows efficiently and quickly.And if in the future I need even more storage, I can expand its storage capacity to reach a 2.5” HDD or 1TB SSD. Nevertheless, the storage capacity that this laptop has now is more than enough to store my files, documents, media, and even some large applications.Therefore, I am quite pleased with my laptop because it came with a Celeron Intel N5095 processor, it works at a speed of 2.0 GHz, but it can reach speeds up to 2.9GHz, this laptop has a 4-core configuration, it is currently running on the latest Windows 11 operating system, it has a cooling fan to prevent overheating, and I can always add more SSD or HDD storage to increase its storage capacity in the future if I need to.

review_title: Needed a decent laptop for my DJ setup
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on October 5, 2023
review_text: I was working with an older laptop that started struggling to run the software I need for DJing, even after upgrading. So I just received this laptop yesterday. I'm still delving into it to get my settings and configuration the way I want, but right out of the box, I can already tell this will work just fine.When it comes to the "load" (strain on the system), if it's too high, the music clips or stutters, which is death if you're DJing live. There are a few other settings that deal with latency as well that matters. This laptop is more than powerful enough to deal with it all from what I've seen so far.Overall, it still looks new, it's fairly light and thin, and I haven't found anything that doesn't work. As of now, I'm happy with the purchase. It's a good product at a decent price.

review_title: Do the ram upgrade and hard drive upgrade .
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on December 6, 2023

review_title: 1st one was a lemon. 2nd one work great.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on January 5, 2024
review_text: I had to return the first laptop I received as it kept restarting on its own. It did it literally as soon as I turned it on the first time, I couldn't even set up my account. Finally got it set up, worked good for a few days and started restarting again. The 2nd one has worked flawlessly so far and I couldn't be happier. I use it for editing 1080 videos for YouTube, it's very fast. It may handle 4k, not sure yet. The battery life is about 6-7 hours, so not bad. Your taking a chance on getting a lemon but just make sure u use it thoughroughly when u buy to make sure it's not a lemon and can return it if so. I do recommend this laptop.

review_title: “Excellent” Used Condition Is Not Worth It
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on April 1, 2024
review_text: I bought my first laptop from them and I was able to log on and it worked and was in excellent used condition and then the screen just went black and it didn’t work at all within a few days. I exchanged it for the exact same replacement item and they sent me with with a broken / loose screen hinge so it won’t stay at any angle other than fully open/ leaned back or fully closed and it had lots of dents, you could tell it was an aftermarket replacement screen (it was shinier than Mac original) and had a weird smell as it hadn’t even been wiped down. I returned this one and decided to look at Best Buy instead and now this company says that they refunded my money to my Amazon account but they have not. My money is nowhere to be found even though they claim my return was approved and that they refunded my original payment method (Amazon gift card). I had to open an A to Z Amazon claim and I am still waiting for my return money to be processed…

review_text: Very nice MacBook Air, mine looked brand new with no damage or wear at all.  Worked perfectly from first second.  The only drawback is the battery life, its REALLY bad.  You can put it to sleep and within a few hours its already lost 25% or more.  Not sure how much it would cost to get new battery but, still this is a GREAT deal vs. the price of a brand new MacBook.  Overall would recommend it though, just know you'll probably be needing to stay near a power source.

review_title: Nice machine. SO much faster for the web than my 5 year old Windows laptop
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on July 24, 2020
review_text: I am still not entirely used to a Chromebook (CB), but I like them. This Acer is my second CB. It has a larger screen and better keyboard than my first and handles internet traffic so much faster than my laptop. There are still somethings about CB that I don't understand, and I miss certain Windows like features but over all I am very satisfied with it. It is not a touch screen.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on October 24, 2020
review_text: We got this for our daughter to use when the 2020/2021 school year started and our school district was doing virtual school. It has held up, and we will continue to use it since she isn't going back to in-person learning any time soon. It handles Zoom calls just fine, but the Chrome OS doesn't allow all of the Zoom features (customized backgrounds). That's fine since it keeps my daughter focusing on the school work and not playing with the app. Batter life hasn't been an issue when she unplugs it to do Physical Education videos in the living room.  Her headphones with inline microphone work just fine. As a Windows user, I had to figure out the Chrome OS interface and where things are located, but its fairly intuitive and online help is readily available. Its not that different from the OS on my Droid Phone. We like the full keyboard layout.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on January 12, 2024

review_title: is the screen defective or just very bad?
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on December 17, 2022
review_text: The screen is unbearable and it will have to go back.  It's hurting my eyes.  I am constantly adjusting the angle and it is always either washed out or very dark in some part of the screen and furthermore has a faint fuzziness. This is not side viewing, no, this is straight on and so bad it surprises me this this model got any good reviews.  One person gave it 3 stars for the not so good screen.  If their screen was as bad as this one it would not have been a 3.  I had a 14" Acer that was great and years older than this one; it's updates expired. Perhaps this particular machine is defective, but I suggest you not take a chance with this model.  The bigger screen, the number pad, the reasonable AUE, and the good price are not worth hurting your eyes!!

review_title: Budget laptop easy to use and great for accessing youtube videos
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on July 6, 2023
review_text: Retired after 39 years as systems analyst and now enjoy my 5 bedroom house which my stepdaighter bought for me and my wife of 28 uears. It has 4 bedrooms and 2 bathrooms in the main house and the garage is converted to a bedroom and bathroom. It has a pool and jacuzzi in the back yard. I enjoy watching youtube  videos on my laptop so when my laptop failed a few week ago I ordered a refurbished Lenovo Chromebook last week and received it today.It plays my Youtube videos prrfectly which is great as I am retired andenjoy Youtube daily.The only thing missing is cd or dvd player. As i received Youtube and Amazon prime a few months ago as part of my hish sevice a few months ago. I am enjoying the channels immensely being an 11 year member of Amazon Prime.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on March 17, 2024
review_text: Chromebooks have truly become a disposable commodity. My college daughter had an ASUS that died and needed one ASAP before she returned to classes after Spring Break. As long as it worked, for seventy bucks I was going to be happy. For a "Refreshed" computer, I was more than happy with this Lenovo 300e. Yeah, it doesn't have the touch screen and yes, there are some minor cosmetic blemishes. Also, the "5" key has a bit of an extra click to it.That's all that wrong with it though. For what it is, it is powerful and quick enough. The screen and audio are good, and the keyboard is surprisingly high quality. The trackpad works nicely, and the battery life is good. I wish it had a 2nd USB C port, but just about everything else is there and works or isn't needed. My daughter is happy with it and says it is as good or better than her previous Chromebook.~ Kort

review_title: A Sleek and Powerful Ultra-Thin Laptop - A Perfect Choice for Work and Entertainment!
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on March 12, 2023
review_text: I recently purchased a 3rd ASUS Laptop L510 Ultra Thin Laptop and I am thrilled with my purchases. This laptop has exceeded my expectations in every way. The 15.6” FHD display is stunning, offering crystal-clear visuals that are perfect for both work and entertainment.The Intel Celeron N4020 Processor is incredibly fast and efficient, ensuring that I can multitask without any lag or delay. I can easily run multiple programs at once, stream movies, and browse the web without any issues.The 4GB of RAM is perfect for my needs and provides ample space for all of my important files and documents. I have been able to store all of my important files, photos, and music without any problems.The ultra-thin design is sleek and modern, making it easy to carry around with me wherever I go. It is lightweight and compact, making it perfect for travel or taking to the office.Overall, I highly recommend the ASUS Laptop L510 Ultra Thin Laptop to anyone in need of a reliable, fast, and efficient laptop. It is an excellent choice for both personal and professional use, and I am confident that it will meet all of your needs and exceed your expectations. Five stars!

review_title: RUNAWAY!!!! SO SLOW IT GLITCHES PLAYING MUSIC!!!
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on May 4, 2024
review_text: This is the worst laptop I've ever bought, DO NOT PURCHASE IT! I don't know if the ever reviewers got a different laptop but it's so slow it's unusable! I used to be an ASUS Laptop fan, because I had great previous products with them. This one is so slow it's unusable. You CANNOT have two programs open at the same time. You CANNOT have 5 tabs open at the same time. It's that bad, it will glitch out while I'm listening to music so much so that the music makes a horrible sound. It genuinely unusable. I made the mistake of following the other reviews that said "it gets better when you remove Microsoft S" and "it gets faster when you get through all the updates." I should not have relied on those reviews because I went past my return date because I just had to get through "one more update" then it would be fast. IT NEVER WORKED. IT HAS ALWAYS IMPOSSIBLY SLOW! DO NOT TRUST REVIEWS ABOUT UPDATES! RUNAWAY FROM THIS COMPUTER AND SAVE YOURSELF FROM AMAZON COSTUMER SERVICE HELL! I have reached out to Amazon 4 times about this issue and 4 times they tell me they were going to give me a refund and 4 times there is nothing. I used to think Amazon Costumer service was good but now Ive realized it's just as poor as the rest and full of empty promises to get you off the chat. Finally, I have since realized that the computer is missing a screw, which makes me question the quality but I'm still not allowed to return it. RUNAWAY!!! WOULD GIVE NEGATIVE STARS!!!

review_title: Great PC Value: Light, Sleek & Fast
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on September 10, 2021
review_text: I bought this Asus laptop because I bought a piece of design equipment that is run solely by software that requires Windows operating system. Since it will be dedicated to just this operation, I wanted an inexpensive but powerful laptop with a large clear screen. The 15.6" screen is sharp, clear and visible from a distance and different angles without much distortion that you often find when viewing laptop screens from an angle. This Asus running Windows 10 Home (I converted it from Windows 10 S mode) runs my design program perfectly without any lag in speed or function. It's lightweight, sleek, the keyboard is easy to type on and colors render quite nicely on the screen. While it may not be up to gaming (not a gamer here) it's a perfect laptop for a student who needs basic computing needs and like me, someone who needs to run a windows-exclusive design program.Full disclosure: By submitting this I may qualify for an additional 90 day warranty. Why wouldn't I? I was about to submit my positive review anyway when I got he email offering the additional warranty. I do like this laptop very much ... and that's coming from a dedicated Macintosh user! I definitely recommend this Asus L510 laptop. You can't go wrong.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on December 23, 2023
review_text: I bought this laptop PC as a secondary laptop due to the low price. It has a 15.6 in. monitor with a matte display. I had an ASUS PC before and ASUS laptops are definitely high quality. You will definitely need to make some adjustments to make this laptop to run at an acceptable normal speed: 1. Go to the Microsoft store to permanently disable the Windows S-Mode 2. Search Google Chrome on how to speed up Windows 11. After doing so this PC runs fairly fast. Note: I had difficulty setting my Microsoft profile due to the fact that Microsoft would not promptly send me a required code to my email; Microsoft was very slow and I did not receive the code until the following day. Don't fault ASUS, fault Microsoft regarding this. I would recommend this laptop to anyone that wants do basic stuff like surfing the internet and/or using Office or 365.

review_title: It will get the job done
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on May 7, 2024
review_text: We use this for our small decal maker and our other small computer needs and after a yr it still has no issues speed is great and networking is no problem when needed we will buy another one

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on June 5, 2024
review_text: I ordered this laptop because my previous one suddenly died. It was on sale and it had many good reviews so I thought everything was good. The shipping was fast and the laptop was packaged well with nothing wrong cosmetic wise. However, the trouble started when I turned on the laptop. I noticed that it was very slow and took over five hours to completely update and process everything. I figured that it was just slow to update. Thats just the thrills that come with owning a computer. It was after I had had it for about a week that I decided enough was enough. It could barely open two tabs without crashing or giving me an error message. I couldn’t open apps without five to ten minutes of waiting and there was multiple times where it completely froze and I couldn’t even shut it down. The trackpad response was also slow compared to my other laptops. Positives I guess would be that the battery is long lasting and the speakers are have quality and clear sound. It might work better for someone else and I just got a faulty product. I just personally do not recommend this laptop.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on May 9, 2024
review_text: The best chrome book i got, if you're student looking for a good chrome book i will definitely recommended to order this one.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on March 14, 2023
review_text: I do QA testing for K-12 student use of testing and assessment applications used across my state.  I try to duplicate what students have on hand so I can best replicate their usage environment.  The Samsung CB actually worked too well.  It performed better than some of the devices I was seeking to replicate.  Response to the applications prompts was quick and screen resolution was sharp and displayed the assessment content clearly.  The accommodations components, visual enhancements and the text to speech reader were excellent and performed very well.  Outside of the QA work, this device streamed Internet content very well and the audio was clear.  Access to and performance of Google Apps and O365 Apps did very well and I found no issues.  The audio jack can handle headphones/mic combo. Battery life was good as well, lasting over 6 hours of continual pounding and high end development use.  This is my 2nd Samsung CB.  The first lasted 5+ years and held up to a lot of development use.  I see this new unit doing the same.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on March 29, 2024
review_text: When it arrived it had the bare minimum packaging possible. Laptop free floated in a box 3 times too big. Thankfully I didn't notice any damage from shipping.When I got it out of the box it had a full battery that died in 30 minutes just doing the setup. I also noticed a super bad screen burn, nice. Then to my great surprise the charger that came with the laptop plugged right in and charged a grand total of 2%. Every time I turn on the laptop there's a giant warning: "THIS CHARGER IS NOT CORRECT AND WILL NOT CHARGE THIS LAPTOP".  When inspecting the charger the plastic top is busted off.After using this Laptop for a few days it never charged over 2%. Burn in on the screen is super distracting. And trying to do anything like watching a video or downloading a game it immediately dies. Tried customer support, Amazon did nothing, the seller surprise surprise did nothing.To recap this re-manufactured laptop came in less packaging than boardgames from Amazon do. There is screen burn in and it's not subtle. Came with the wrong charger also busted no less. And the battery is shot.At the very least a re-manufactured laptop should have the screen, battery, and charger replaced AT THE BARE MINIMUM! I did not know it was possible to screw up this.For the price I can deal with everything but one thing. Put. The. Right. Charger. In. The. Box.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on June 4, 2024
review_text: The HP Chromebook 11-inch Laptop is a compact powerhouse that seamlessly integrates productivity and portability. Its MediaTek MT8183 processor coupled with 4 GB RAM ensures smooth multitasking, making it perfect for work or study. With 32 GB eMMC storage, you'll have ample space for all your documents and media. The vibrant 11.6-inch HD display offers crisp visuals, enhancing your viewing experience. Plus, with Chrome OS™, you'll enjoy fast boot-up times and access to a wide array of apps from the Google Play Store, making it an excellent choice for those seeking efficiency and versatility in a sleek package.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on April 30, 2023
review_text: I've had this Chromebook for a few months. I needed to sell my Macbook Pro due to financial issues, so I got this and was definitely worried because of the iffy reputation of Chromebooks. It works really great, though. It's a little bit slower than my Macbook, but I was expecting it to be WAY slower. I don't like that there's no keyboard backlight - makes it harder to use at night. I don't really like that there's no actual desktop and no way to actually fully shut it down, but that's a Chromebook problem in general, not specific to this version. Other than those minor issues, it's great. 9/10. Definitely a good buy/a steal!

review_title: Amazing value, amazing battery life- a couple frustrating issues.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on May 29, 2022
review_text: This is my first Chromebook, and overall I’m quite pleased with the purchase.  I’m mainly going to be using it for basic internet browsing and writing, so when I was shopping for the right model I was favoring cost, weight and battery life over other features like screen size and processing power. I ultimately felt this was the best balance of weight and battery life for the price.  I definitely wasn’t wrong about the battery life. I’m amazed. This thing lasts and lasts.  It’s not the fastest computer but it suffices for my use case.Two things that bother me.This first is the lack of an illuminated keyboard.  I knew it lacked one going into it, so I can’t complain that much. I just didn’t realize how much I’ve come to rely on it on my other laptops. I’m often using the computer in dark environments, where it’s difficult to see the keys.  Again, I knew this wasn’t an included feature, so this isn’t really a complaint as much as something to give extra consideration to before purchasing. With that being said, even with the lack of the illuminated keyboard, I don’t regret the purchase, and would buy again.Which takes me to the second point. There is an issue with some of the video playback. In extra bright scenes in videos on YouTube and elsewhere, there is some discoloration in the highlights. Meaning, that in certain areas of the video, particularly that are white, there is some blue artifacts/pixelation happening. I have confirmed that this is an issue with this model and have seen it replicated in floor models at Best Buy and heard other people complain about this. I’m frustrated that HP has allowed this to continue to be a problem without offering a fix. As I said, most of my use cases involve writing; so video watching isn’t high up on my list of priorities. If it was, this would be a much bigger problem for me.Overall, I’m pleased with the purchase given the price, and recommend it for anybody who is looking for an inexpensive, long battery life Chromebook option.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on April 20, 2024
review_text: It’s a lightweight compact computer that’s perfect for traveling.

review_title: Excellent, the right size for me and works great!

review_text: I'm always a little leery of buying refurbished instead of new. However, this nice smaller Chromebook seems to be working fine so far! I really appreciate the size (I can easily hold it in my lap) as well as the lower cost (I'm a cheapskate!). Be aware that like many older Chromebooks, you may not be able to update the Chrome. However, I am mainly using this as an offline writing device, so as long as I can get access to Google Docs and Drive, as well as my email, that's not a problem for me.

review_text: This is about the 7th or 8th Chromebook in the family and happy so far. Was looking for something something kids could abuse and also suitable for semi-rough treatment at the beach, camping, etc. Also wanted excellent battery life, which this has (non-touch screen version), typically 11 hrs plus at about 80% brightness. Is very snappy with new processor. Screen isn't the highest quality but better than expected at this price. All-plastic build, but very sturdy, and more compact than earlier models due to smaller bezels. And it gets updates until June, 2028.

review_title: Impossible to Exit Guest Mode--No Way to Make It Your Personal Chromebook
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on June 14, 2024
review_text: I am thinking I will have to return this HP Chromebook which I bought to replace my husband's aging Chromebook that was giving him problems. However, this one has some kind of glitch that does not recognize the WiFi connection and perpetually urges you to choose another option (even when connected) and only allows browsing in Guest Mode. Settings shows nothing helpful to address the problem because it is perpetually in Guest Mode. The Factory reset recommended action of pressing Ctrl + Alt + Shift + r does nothing. No ability to restart or reset this Chrome device.  Every time it is turned off and back on, it must "determine device configuration" all over again and just spins and spins. So don't buy unless you don't mind being a permanent "guest browser."

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on September 21, 2021
review_text: I really like this computer..I just use it for fantasy sports on Yahoo and some other web surfing but I really like it.. I've previously owned larger HP ones and I wanted to go with something different and a chrome operating system because I am tired of windows and their non stop updates.. First of all battery life is excellent, once you close the computer it sleeps and uses almost zero battery, then when you open it it's immediately ready to use, doesn't have to boot up or anything. Also the charging port is the same upside down or right side up! You don't have to fiddle with the port to rightly plug it in.  Important to note, set-up was a little tricky as you have to sign in as a user/ owner to take it out of "guest mode" which allows you to bookmark your favorite pages to immediately have access to your faves, that involves setting up a Google Gmail account or using an existing one u have, other than that it's a handy, simple unit that is very well worth the price.  I suggest googling the process if you are unsure.. I'm not very computer savvy but I figured it out in a matter of minutes 😁 I recommend this computer.. The mousepad is also a simple tool, which has left click and right click on the pad without extra buttons so you will have to get used to that I do suggest maybe getting an actual mouse and mousepad because the panel is a little tricky to navigate other than that a great 👍 item

review_title: Good quality, fast and well worth the money.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on October 13, 2022
review_text: Screen quality is great. It charges quickly and the battery charge lasts a very long time. The only thing I could find some might find as an irritant is that you must readjust the screen if you move the Chromebook to different locations to have it back in a correct position to see picture perfect on the screen. This I only mention because I find myself needing to readjust screen occasionally to see the picture perfect on the screen. Of course, this does not take away any points from my 5 Star rating as this is the only thing I could find I would mention to others as something they may not find perfect.

review_title: You get what you pay for
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on July 4, 2021
review_text: This definitely isn't anything you want to be gaming on because the CPU usage just gets so high. Mind you, it would get to 99% CPU usage with no apps open, only running the chrome browser with ONE tab open watching Netflix. I bought this just for basic usage of online browsing, watching Netflix or YouTube, checking emails, listen to music (the speakers are a bit low, wish it was a little louder) and just again very basic things. It did crash on me once while again just one tab opened watching Netflix. It would react to my clicking but it was very delayed and slow. Sometimes moving the cursor around is also a little delayed so it doesn't have the best reaction time when clicking on something. It's not touch screen and no backlit keyboard but it wasn't something I was personally interested in and I don't believe it mentions it in the ads either. Arrived next day and it's very lightweight, does feel a little like cheapish plastic so be careful moving the screen back and forth but the overall packaging was nice and new. You get what you pay for and I really wasn't expecting much from it. If you buy this with LOW expectations and for simple/basic use then it's a great little Chromebook. I've deleted all extra apps that came preinstalled that I personally didn't need and made sure everything is updated and clean. Sometimes your Chrome extensions can make Chrome use up a lot of CPU so be on the lookout for that (I decided to remove some extensions but yet the Chromebook does still take up a lot of space). Overall a great little Chromebook for travel but just don't expect anything crazy or anything like a laptop. This isn't a laptop, its a Chromebook. So no Windows OS just Chrome. Think of it like an android tablet with a keyboard really lol keeping those things in mind and making sure not too many things are running at a time, you'll have a good experience with it!

review_text: This was a very great guy. The laptop works great. The packaging was packed very well and was safe. It wasn't broken whenever I got it. Nothing was missing. review_date: Reviewed in the United States on September 12, 2021
review_text: This bad boy does exactly what I need it to do. I’m not a big PC gamer, I’m not operating heavy-duty software, and all the big projects I do are on my work PC. This buddy is for internet and Google docs/sheets work. And it does that spectacularly. I haven’t bought a new “laptop” in ages so it’s great to have a light little internet boy that I can tote around. I’ll miss the disc drive but I know a friend with an external. For the price, I’m super pleased! Plus, by giving this review, I’m getting a 90 day warranty extension.EDIT: soooooo, that warranty is hard to get, haha! But I got this on discount. It’s still reliable. They’ll make you jumps thru some HOOPS for that warranty. It still works fine. Expect the normal… meh-ness of any Windows based machine. It is what you’re paying for, but it’s good for what it is!

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on February 21, 2023
review_text: Here are my experiences with this computer:1) Good battery life if not streaming video.  It can easily last you 10 to 14 hours.  However, the battery indicator is not accurate.  It will tell you that you have 10 hours of battery in one minute, and then 14 hours the next minute, and in less than 30 seconds, it tells you I have only 8 hours left.2) The Bluetooth connection is completely unreliable.  I have two devices attached using Bluetooth, a headphone, and a mouse.  They take turns disappearing from the connection.  And many times, the Bluetooth will shut off altogether by itself.  Annoyingly, it happens every 4 to 5 hours meaning that if I am working on this computer, I have to reboot the computer at least 2 to 3 times a day to keep using Bluetooth.3) Internet WiFi is very weak using this computer.  If you are streaming movies and browsing the Internet at the same time using different windows, the computer will slow down to ... let's say, no response at all.4) Very light, easy to carry around.5) The screen quality is very poor, so poor that I got headaches after using it for a day.  However, it is still nice when you are watching HD movies.6) Good price.  For the price I paid, no reason to complain too much.

review_title: Minor issues, but clean and working
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on August 29, 2023
review_text: These rugged Latitude 5414s are in good working order.  I bought two of them for field employees.  ONE out of two had some minor scratches and blemishes, but barely noticeable.  They came preloaded with Windows 10, but the software used to load and parititon were not recognizable to me.  Also, it was the 1903 version so outdated and unsupported.  So I opted to reload everything with a base copy of Win10 22H2.  Everything loaded fine.  Had to change the BIOS to load from external USB in EUFI mode.  No big deal there.  Screens were clean and scratch free.  All keyboard keys and touch pads were very clean and in working order.  Touch screen works great.The only other thing is that I am guessing one of these motherboards must have been replaced during the "renewing" process.  Upon reload, one of the laptops automatically activated its Windows digital license, whereas the other did not have one.  So I had to purchase an OEM Win10 key to activate the second one (not a big expense).  Othe than the issues mentioned above, everything works great.All is as described in the description.  I would buy from them again.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on May 16, 2024
review_text: Update - Been a few weeks since I first used the laptop but today I wanted to install some additional software.  It's a BUST, B and N keys no longer work.  So, this laptop worked for approximately four hours and now, unless I can figure how to get the B and N keys to work, it's a door stop.Up front I wanted to say it's my fault.  I was looking for a small rugged Windows computer to use with a few mechanic programs - mainly ForScan.  Since I would take it while traveling it had to be tough, resistant to dust, not too heavy, and a screen I could see in sunlight.  This Dell has almost all of my needs - it is definitely tough.  It has dust ports covering everything.  It appears the battery and perhaps HHD are also accessible from each side.  I'm guessing it's the battery and HHD but with no manual, I could be wrong.  I used the Dell for the first time yesterday and after an long setup time; not blaming the Dell but trying to get through Windows caused me to reboot the laptop three times when Microsoft froze.  After setup and some personal software installed, I used the Dell on battery for about 90-mins without issue.  Sitting in my truck with the sun beating in, I was able to read the screen and that was a good thing.  My only issue and it's my fault, is the Dell is larger than I was expecting.  Of course it is heavy - given it's design and construction that wasn't a surprise and since it's in my truck 90% of the time or on my work bench, I don't think the weight will be a problem.  So, after just 48-hrs of use, we are happy.  Getting ready for a four month overlanding adventure and the Dell is going along, so we'll see if I need to update my review.

review_text: I want to say I love this, but I don't know if I do. Only the laptop in the box, no charge on the laptop and no charging cord to turn it on. "UPDATE"- I contacted the company and they sent my cord right out, I bought this because my new laptop case fell apart at 3 months old, this rugged case should last and last. It doesn't have 10 key, but I can live with that. Laptop is functioning well and it's very sturdy so I am very happy now. Thanks for getting my charging cord right to me after I contacted you!

review_title: A Remarkable Deal That Beats The newer models
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on July 17, 2023
review_text: Investing in a refurbished laptop might seem like a gamble, but when it comes to the Dell Latitude 7390, it's a bet you're sure to win. Having recently acquired a refurbished model of this laptop, I can say with confidence that its performance and value are simply incomparable.First off, the durability of the Latitude 7390 is truly commendable. Despite being refurbished, the build quality is superb, rivaling and even surpassing many brand-new laptops on the market. This is a laptop designed for longevity, capable of withstanding daily use over extended periods without a hitch.The display quality of the Latitude 7390 deserves special mention. The sharp, vibrant visuals elevate everyday tasks, transforming ordinary browsing, streaming, or working sessions into an enjoyable experience. For those who prioritize display quality, this laptop will not disappoint.In terms of performance, the Latitude 7390 does more than just get the job done—it excels at it. Whether you're multitasking with numerous apps, browsing heavy websites, or running demanding software, this laptop maintains a smooth, lag-free operation, significantly boosting your productivity.Perhaps the most appealing aspect of the Latitude 7390 is the value it offers. When compared to brand-new laptops, which can cost twice as much, the superior quality and performance of this refurbished model make it an absolute steal. It's a testament to the fact that a hefty price tag doesn't always equate to better quality or performance.In conclusion, if you're considering investing in a laptop, I highly recommend giving the refurbished Dell Latitude 7390 a chance. Its blend of durability, impressive display, smooth performance, and outstanding value make it a choice that you won't regret.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on September 27, 2022
review_text: I've spent quite some time looking for a cheap sub 300$ laptop that has FHD, not a Celeron CPU and not a Chromebook running from a SD card. Just when i was about to lose hope i decided to try one more time and found this absolute gem. I liked it so much i bought another one for my wife even though she has a 17" gaming laptop already but she likes this small tough guy. I'd buy one for my cats. I convinced some of my friends to buy these while they last. I absolutely LOVE it.Pros:- Beautiful FHD ips display- Good performance for its hardware. Cant play any games but im streaming to it from my gaming PC, just cuz i could.- Decent battery life- Both of the laptops i bought have touchscreen- Can be charged from usb-c, meaning i can keep it in my car without even bothering to take if home for charging (but i still do because i like to carry it with me)- Small and light- Dirt cheap- Lots of ports- Good materials and feels very well builtCons:- Fingerprint scanner is unusable. I was thinking it was just my laptop but the second one has the same exact issue. Might be Win11 related or something else. Updated all drivers, reinstalled DellVault, nothing changed.- Sound is just "meh". Not bad but could be a little louder.

review_title: Great laptop, does get very hot though.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on July 29, 2023
review_text: I really enjoy this laptop, I think it runs fast, has a lot of storage for what I need, and gets the job done. Definitely not a gaming computer by any means, even small games make this thing turn into a furnace. Just load up minecraft and you have the worlds hottest heating pad, works great for cramps! An external fan seems to work as well as keeping the laptop elevated at an angle so the vents on the bottom have airflow. Great laptop for the price.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on June 19, 2023
review_text: Looked like new.  It was clean and ours didn't even a scratch on it.I turned it on and entered my wifi password and then my MS login and waited about 10 minutes while it installed everything including my Office 360 apps.  It prompted for face recognition which I declined and a PIN which I setup.  This was about the easiest setup I have ever experienced.For anything upto serious gamer or BitCoin mining this little wonder can do it.  It was $1800 high end business laptop a few years ago and for a student, general small business user or just someone who wants a light fairly fast machine this does it.It is only 13 inch but the screen is very sharp and bright enough to be a pleasure to use.  Having older eyes I set the display to full HD (1920x1080) with scale set to 175% which just allows a Word Doc in screen width display to be easy to work with.While this unit comes with a 256GB Sata SSD, it will accept a tb NVMe/PCIe M.2 by just swapping.  Same socket supports both and the bios recognizes either so I upgraded to a Crucial 4tb drive for my wife who needs a large pile of music and video as a dance teacher.  I just made a Win 10 boot usb drive, took 5 minutes and 7 screws to physically swap and then followed the instructions as it booted.  Yes, it recognizes the whole 4tb as a single drive.  With the SSD on sale, for around $300 total I ended up with a nice looking, nice feel, 4tb laptop that weighs 3.5 pounds.

review_title: Was hesitant at first, but very happy

review_text: (Husband posting on wife's account). Did my research and felt this was an awesome deal. Was a little nervous as there were only a few reviews. review_text: So far I like everything about this renewed laptop.. It is like new. I had a 11.6" laptop and this 13.3" laptop is just barely larger even though the screen is 15% larger. This PC is also a much faster, Quad core compared to Dual and has more Ram and storage. The display is very nice, FHD. I use this laptop almost all day, so I leave it plugged in. It has a much larger power connection and is much more rugged. On my old laptop, the power connection was very small and weak and the power would keep going out, which meant I could not use or charge it. Buying this laptop is like getting a brand new $1500 laptop for $200. Not sure about the battery since I don't use it on battery much. I guess we will see.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on February 3, 2024
review_text: Right up front, I'm reviewing a Dell Latitude 5300 2-in-1 with an I7, and I am vendor-agnostic.  The unit that I'm reviewing came from a recent Woot! purchase, which may or may not reflect the vendor in this thread.The laptop that I received was marketed as "scratch and dent" but was, in fact, cosmetically flawless.The only complaint I would have is that that the battery was:A) low-capacity andB) 3 years oldLithium-Ion batteries only survive ~500 full charge cycles, which for must users works out to about 2 years of service.  In this case, the service tag for the system I received told me the laptop is/was just shy of 3 years old.  I would expect the battery to be shot , and a cost-saving measure refurbishers are unlikely to replace shot batteries.At the age and price-point of these systems, you should assume that you'll need to incur the extra cost of a new battery.  Additionally, the replacement long-capacity battery for this laptop is both cheap and super easy to replace if you have the correct screwdriver.The laptop itself legitimately runs Windows 11, is fast, and features an amazing touch screen.  Additionally, the system is easily upgraded to 32GB of RAM in addition to pretty much the NVME drive of your capacity choice.If you're willing to make the effort to replace the battery, this purchase is a no-brainer.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on October 28, 2023
review_text: The good:Did a lot if searching and this seemed to be the best option for the price. Bought fir mynikdest who is going off to college soon and didn't want to spend 2k so went this route instead. With an i7, 16 gigs or RAM, and a 522Gb M.2 hard drive, it's gotbokenty of juice for her computing and digital art needs. Had to drop another $80 on a Dell stylus but well worth it.The Bad:Although it does come with 16Gb of SK Hynix DDR4 RAM, it's in the firm of a single DIMM instead of 2 which limits the speed and performance a bit as single Chanel memory. The battery seems to go pretty fast. I'm guessing it's the original battery and for the price it's fine. A new Delk replacement is less than $75 so that's ojay too when the time is needed.The 1st one we received had 4 golf ball sized anomalies on the screen in the firm of dark patches. Returned to get a perfect one back so no issues there. I'd just keep an eye out for this. sSince it is a 2 in 1, the screen was pretty important to my daughter since she'll be using it for her digital art among other screen intensive workloads. So keep your eyes peeked incase you get the same.To Sum it Up:It's a great buy for the price and both the memory and M.2 hard drive can be upgraded easily by unscrewing the 10 permanently attached screws on the back cover. 2 DDR4 Memory DIMM slots and 1 M.2 slot available for upgrades.

review_text: I recently purchased the Lenovo 15.6" Laptop, and overall, it's been a reliable companion for my daily tasks. The laptop boasts a decent-sized display, making it suitable for work, entertainment, and everything in between.The build quality is sturdy, and the design is sleek, giving the laptop a professional look. The keyboard is comfortable to type on, with well-spaced keys that provide a satisfying tactile response. The trackpad is responsive and supports multi-touch gestures, enhancing the overall user experience.In terms of performance, the laptop handles everyday computing tasks with ease. Whether it's web browsing, document editing, or streaming content, the processor ensures smooth operation. The included storage capacity is sufficient for basic needs, but users with heavier storage requirements might consider external options.The 15.6" display offers crisp visuals and decent color reproduction, making it suitable for both work and entertainment purposes. The audio quality is adequate for casual use, but for a more immersive experience, external speakers or headphones are recommended.Battery life is respectable, providing enough juice for a full day of moderate usage. However, heavy tasks or gaming may drain the battery more quickly, so it's advisable to keep the charger handy for demanding activities.On the downside, the laptop could benefit from additional ports for increased connectivity options. While it covers the basics, users requiring multiple peripherals may find themselves using a USB hub.In conclusion, the Lenovo 15.6" Laptop is a solid performer for everyday use. It strikes a good balance between affordability and functionality, making it a suitable choice for users seeking a reliable laptop for general tasks.

review_text: I chose one of the few laptops I could get next day, obviously because my wife really needed it for starting classes and I was leaving immediately thereafter.
